DOC.HEAD: Communists Appear Headed for Defeat in Hungary's Elections
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS in 7th graf, `In Hungary...' that there are 386 parliament seats and DELETES incorrect figure from 27th graf; ADDS in 22nd graf, `The Democratic' description of political parties; pickup 28th graf pvs, `But pre-election...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos BUD5,6
DOC.TEXT: Hungarians voted Sunday in their first free elections after 43 years of Communist rule, and early results indicated the party would lose despite taking a lead role in democratic reforms. ``We will be an opposition party,'' said Rezsoe Nyers, chairman of the Socialist Party, which was created by reformers to replace the old Communist Party. ``This, to use a religious term, will be penance for the party.'' ``We will come through it, and we will be strong,'' he added. Premier Miklos Nemeth, a Communist reformer and a key engineer of the nation's conversion to democracy, declared before he voted that he was relinquishing control ``head high and with a clear conscience.'' A report by the official news agency said Nemeth won a parliamentary seat as an independent in a district northeast of Budapest. But his party appeared to have done poorly elsewhere. East Germany held Eastern Europe's first free elections in decades on March 18, and the Communists were rejected there. In Hungary, they competed with 11 other national parties for 386 parliament seats. No party held a clear lead in the early returns. Despite occasional showers, voter turnout appeared heavy in Budapest. Few irregularities were reported by 8 p.m., when polling stations closed. Several international observers had monitored the election. About 7.8 million people were eligible to vote and Janos Nemeth, chairman of the Elections Committee, said preliminary figures showed turnout was more than 70 percent. Premier Nemeth, who voted at a state-run kindergarten serving as one of 11,000 polling stations across the nation, declined to predict the chances of his Socialist Party, which has governed since reform-oriented Communists formed it after defecting from their party in October. ``The only thing I hope for is that a strong government is created,'' Nemeth said, adding that only a government not hamstrung by the opposition can deal with the nation's ailing economy. His comments reflected widespread acceptance, even among Socialists, that his party would not do well despite its role, unique in Eastern Europe, in steering Hungary to democratic reform. Instead of crediting the Socialists for volunteering to play by democratic rules, most voters remember the excesses of more than four decades of one-party rule that have made Communists unpopular throughout the Soviet bloc. ``I won't consider it an act of God if I don't make it into government,'' Nemeth told reporters. ``I will hand over the reins head high and with a clear conscience. I don't have bitterness in my heart but satisfaction.'' The state MTI news agency reported that Nemeth won a parliamentary seat in Szerencs, a village about 70 miles northeast of Budapest, where he ran as an independent. With voters able to vote separately for candidates and parties, Nemeth had one of two chances of election, as an individual candidate or as a nominee of his party on the Budapest regional slate. He would be struck from the party list if he won in Szerencs. Election results trickled in at election commission headquarters in the gothic Parliament building and at the election studio of state television. Officials decided to stay with the familiar method of counting ballots by hand and using computers only to cross-check the tally. In East Germany, by contrast, trends were established soon after polls closed, with West German computer technology quickly delivering results in a system typical of Western election coverage. But Hungarian officials in most districts had tallied less than 25 percent of the vote by early Monday, and final results were not expected before late in the day. The centrist Democratic Forum got the most votes in four districts and led in nine more. The liberal League of Free Democrats got the most votes in one district and led in eight others. The Independent Smallholders, a rural party, led in two districts and the Socialists led in two others. However, no candidate or party gained the absolute majority in any of the districts where counting was complete, and all of those Parliament seats were subject to a second round of voting. Hungary's last elections were in 1947, when the Communists won a relative majority, largely through fraud. A year later, they consolidated power and forced all other parties out of existence. Throughout the monthlong campaign, Socialist candidates attempted to convince the electorate of their commitment to a multiparty system. But pre-election opinion polls indicated the Socialists would finish no higher than fourth place, with a maximum 10 percent of the overall vote. A poll of 5,000 people published by the state MTI news agency less than one hour before polls closed indicated the center-right Hungarian Democratic Forum would finish strongest, with 31 seats. The poll predicted the liberal Free Democrats would win 30 seats, the Independent Smallholders 22; the activist liberal League of Young Democrats 18, and the Socialists eight seats. While proposing a variety of solutions on how to complete the transformation from an ossified command economy to one obeying free market rules, most of the parties competing in some or all of the 176 districts espouse centrist ideas. Election rules call for a second round in case no single party wins an absolute majority Sunday and expectations were high that scattered voter loyalties would force a runoff _ tentatively scheduled for April 8. Even new elections, however, were not expected to determine a clear winner, making a coalition government the most likely scenario. The Socialists were unlikely to play a role much beyond Sunday. Leading parties such as the Democratic Forum and the Free Democrats have repeatedly stated they would reject them as government partners. But Democratic Forum Chairman Jozsef Antall refused to comment Sunday when asked by reporters about possible coalition partners. Asked about his thoughts during balloting, Antall, a medical historian, said: ``We want a free Hungary. And I'm happy that we've come this far.'' Free Democrat leader Janos Kis said he expected his party to be one of the top two finishers. As he waited for a polling booth to become free, Kis explained the ballot to his school-age son. Many of more than a dozen voters questioned at random expressed optimism about the future. But some appeared to carry the scars of the past. ``This is a great day in our country's history,'' declared Democratic Forum supporter Bela Kiraly, 50. ``I'm sure it marks a new beginning.'' His wife, Irene, also 50, said she voted for the Democratic Forum on the national list of candidates and for the Free Democrats on the local slate ``because the more diversity in Parliament, the better. ``If any one party becomes too strong, we might return to the same situation we've had for 40 years,'' she said, referring to past Communist rule. A 77-year old woman refused to give her name and preference, but suggested she was sceptical that democracy had arrived to stay in Hungary. ``I've survived too many systems to tell anybody who I vote for,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Lawsuit Filed in Death of Picket
DOC.TEXT: The widow and children of a Greyhound bus driver who was killed on a picket line have filed a $50 million lawsuit against the company and the replacement driver of the bus that crushed him. Robert Waterhouse, 59, was killed March 3 on the second day of a nationwide strike against Greyhound Lines Inc. He was crushed against a wall by the bus. There have been numerous violent incidents since, including several cases in which gunshots were fired at buses. Federal mediators have tried unsuccessfully to restart talks in the pay dispute between Greyhound and the Amalgamated Council of Local Greyhound Unions, which represents the 6,300 drivers and 3,000 other Greyhound workers. Police are still investigating Waterhouse's death, and the Shasta County district attorney is expected to decide next week whether to file criminal charges. The wrongful death suit filed in Shasta County Superior Court names Greyhound and the replacement driver hired for the strike, Theodore Graham Jr. of Portland, Ore. The complaint alleges that Greyhound was negligent in hiring Graham ``in that Graham was not qualified in training and disposition to drive a passenger bus.'' The suit also alleges that the company employed nonunion drivers in ``an illegal attempt at strikebreaking and union-breaking.'' Waterhouse was only months away from retirement after 32 years with Greyhound.

DOC.HEAD: Rotary To Open First Club in Soviet Union
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with comments from Rotary president after return from Moscow. No pickup
DOC.HEAD: jwhofonscg
DOC.TEXT: The first Rotary club in the Soviet Union has been officially established after several years of behind-the-scenes efforts, the president of the international service organization said Sunday. A tired but happy Hugh Archer, president of Rotary International, said three years of contacts between Soviet ambassadors and Rotary officials from around the world led to his final journey this weekend through the Soviet bureaucracy. ``It was difficult from the standpoint of intrigue, in getting the word to the person who could help us,'' Archer said in a telephone interview Sunday night after returning from to Moscow. ``Nobody there wishes to speak as an individual. What we had to do was get a lot of people convinced that it was OK to have a Rotary club started in Moscow.'' Archer finally got approval from Soviet officials for a provisional club that will initially be made up of about 25 business and professional people from Moscow. Rotary International, which has over 1 million members in more than 100 countries, has forged growing links with Eastern Europe in recent years. In June 1989, Rotary established its first clubs in Poland and Hungary since World War II, said John O'Brien, a spokesman for Rotary International, based in suburban Evanston, Ill. Archer first met with Soviet officials in December to explore the possibilities of opening a club in Moscow. He also visited a group eager to form a club in Tallinn, the capital of the Soviet republic of Estonia. In a key discussion Saturday with Deputy Minister of Foreign Affairs Vladimir Petrovsky, Archer said he received assurances the club can meet and select members without surveillance or restrictions and that it will be allowed to maintain contacts with clubs in other countries and contribute financially to the association. Rotary's constitution prohibits it from becoming part of another organization or being restricted by government or political forces. ``It all follows from (Soviet President Mikhail) Gorbachev because of his reforms that sort of paved the way,'' O'Brien said. ``But Rotary has not gone cap in hand begging to open a club. The members of the provisional club in Moscow, who have been holding informal meetings for the past six months, range in age from 30 to 50. They include two lawyers, three businessmen, a theater manager and the head of a translation service. Archer said the group was delighted when told of the agreement and immediately began discussing ideas, especially exchange programs with other countries involving Rotary members, as well as high school and college students. He said the Soviets at first had trouble understanding that they were expected to help people without receiving anything in return. ``The concept of service as practiced by Rotary and other groups is that you enjoy it'' without expectation of compensation, Archer said. ``I think they got that idea.'' Rotary, founded in Chicago in 1905, is a not-for-profit service organization consisting of business and professional men and women. It sponsors educational and charitable programs and has a budget of $56 million for 1989-90.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Sets Trial Date for Anti-Abortion Law
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge on Monday extended a restraining order against enforcement of the most restrictive U.S. abortion law. U.S. District Judge Alex Munson had issued a temporary restraining order Friday, a few hours after a group of Guam residents and medical groups filed a class-action suit. On Monday, he extended the order until May 8, when a trial on the suit is scheduled to begin. ``We're very happy,'' said Anita Arriola, the plaintiffs' attorney. The law prohibits abortions except when a pregnancy endangers the life of the mother. It makes it a third-degree felony to perform an abortion or aid in the procedure, a misdemeanor for a woman to solicit or have an abortion and a misdemeanor for a person to solicit a woman to have an abortion. The law in this Pacific territory is seen by abortion opponents as a potential vehicle to challenge the U.S. Supreme Court's Roe vs. Wade decision that legalized abortion. The Guam law provides for a referendum in the Nov. 6 general election for Guam voters to decide whether to retain or reject the abortion ban. Janet Benshoof, director of the American Civil Liberties Union's Reproductive Freedom Project defied the law last Tuesday when she publicly encouraged women seeking abortions to have them done in Hawaii. She was charged in the territorial Supreme Court with solicitation to commit abortion, a misdemeanor. Among those named in the suit is Gov. Joseph Ada, who signed the measure into law March 19. The plaintiffs include ``Maria Doe,'' a Guam woman who is eight weeks pregnant and wants an abortion; the Guam Society of Obstetricians and Gynecologists, the Guam Nurses Association, an Episcopal priest and three Guam doctors.

DOC.HEAD: Report: 41 Pilots Lost State Driver Licenses
DOC.TEXT: At least 41 pilots of passenger aircraft have lost their Minnesota driver's licenses in the past seven years because of alcohol abuse, according to a published report. Of those who lost licenses, 28 were employed by Egan-based Northwest Airlines, the Star Tribune reported in its Sunday editions. Officials of Northwest and the Federal Aviation Administration declined to comment on the findings, as did a national spokesman for the Air Line Pilots Association. The issue gained widespread attention when three Northwest pilots were arrested this month after a flight from Fargo, N.D., to Minneapolis. The pilots were later fired by Northwest and have been charged with flying an airliner while under the influence of alcohol. The paper made its count using an FAA list of more than 2,000 Minnesota-based pilots who hold an air-transport license, the kind required of airline captains, and a Class 1 medical certificate, the highest available. A pilot must hold a transport license to carry passengers for money, but private pilots also may hold such a license. The pilot list was checked against Department of Public Safety records and court files for alcohol-related driving violations over the past seven years. Of 41 pilots with alcohol offenses, 25 were convicted of drunken driving or equivalent charges and 15 pleaded guilty to lesser charges, which enabled them to avoid reporting their alcohol violations to the FAA, the newspaper said. It didn't list the offense of the 41st pilot. Ten of the pilots had surrendered their driver's licenses for a year at some point rather than take blood-alcohol tests. The FAA has relied on pilots to voluntarily report alcohol convictions to the agency. Pilots often don't do so for fear they'll be diagnosed as alcoholic and lose their licenses to fly, the paper said. A 1987 audit by the U.S. Transportation Department found that three-fourths of all U.S. pilots who were convicted of alcohol-related offenses failed to report them to the FAA, as required. Northwest doesn't ask its pilots to report violations to the company, nor does it routinely check their driving records, which are available to the public, the Star Tribune said. The FAA said last year that it intends to begin matching pilot names with those on the government's National Driver Register, which lists drivers whose licenses have been suspended or revoked. The agency also is seeking authority to cancel the medical certificates of pilots with multiple alcohol offenses and is considering testing pilots after accidents.

DOC.HEAD: Hungarians Begin Voting in First Free Election Since 1947
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with three grafs with polls opening; Pickup 3rd pvs, `In a...'
DOC.TEXT: Hungarians voted Sunday in their first free elections since 1947 and seemed determined to oust the Communists who initiated democratic reform in hopes of gaining credit at the ballot box. Polling stations opened at 6 a.m., with the last scheduled to close 14 hours later. About 7.8 million Hungarians are eligible to vote. Hungarians will choose a 394-seat Parliament in Eastern Europe's second free elections, a week after East Germans backed a center-right movement to lead them to unity with West Germany. In a Soviet bloc rushing toward democracy, Hungary remains unique. While the people forced the Communists in East Germany, Czechoslovakia and Romania to grant demands for democracy, Hungary's Communists initiated reform, then changed their name to the Socialists and said they espoused Western-style Social Democratic ideals. Yet there is little sign voters will reward them. Opinion polls suggest the Socialists will end up with only about 10 percent of the overall vote. In a year of remarkable reforms begun in the fall of 1988, Hungary's Communists pointed the way for Eastern Europe by scrapping their party's guaranteed leading role from the constitution, legalizing a multiparty system, passing a new electoral law and altering the country's name and emblem to wipe out Communist affiliations. Hungary also opened its western border, allowing thousands of East Germans to flee their homeland and helping to bring about the fall of East Germany's hard-line Communist leaders. But those changes were overshadowed by memories of 43 years of Communist rule in Hungary. In 1947 elections, the Communists won a relative majority, largely through fraud. A year later, they consolidated power and forced all other parties out of existence. All opposition parties contesting Sunday's ballot declared themselves open to almost any coalition scenario, but excluded governing with the Socialists. A popular poster from the Hungarian Democratic Forum, one of the leading contenders for power, symbolized the anti-Communist, anti-Soviet slant of the campaign. It showed a bull-necked soldier with the Russian-language caption: ``Comrades, It's all over.'' While united in opposition to communism, Hungarians are unlikely to show a firm preference for any one party. This would require a second round of voting tentatively scheduled April 8. Opinion polls suggested up to 25 percent of the voters were undecided about whom to back Sunday. International groups sent delegations to monitor the elections. Former Vice President Walter Mondale, leading a 50-member group, said there were a ``couple of pimples here and there'' in the campaign, but no major problems. The campaign centered mostly on unpleasant economic truths that are taking the edge off the thrill of choosing a government. Most parties agree that the stultified centralized economy should be converted to one governed by market forces. None can deny the transformation is likely to bring unemployment and still higher prices to a country battling double-digit inflation. The new government also will inherit a $20 billion foreign debt, the highest per capita in Eastern Europe. Another primary issue was Romania's treatment of its ethnic Hungarians. At least seven people were killed last week in ethnic unrest in Transylvania, uniting all Hungarian parties and awakening fears of neighboring Romania. At one opposition rally Friday, a woman expressed concern over any opposition move to accelerate the total withdrawal of Soviet troops, saying she feared a possible Romanian military threat. Twelve parties garnered enough support to run on the national list in the complex electoral system forged by the Communists and opposition last year. Seventeen other parties are running candidates on the local level, with as many as 14 candidates in some races. Twenty-one parties offered no candidates. The six considered most likely to win seats in Parliament are the Hungarian Democratic Forum, the League of Free Democrats, the Independent Smallholders' Party, the governing Socialist Party, the League of Young Democrats and the Social Democratic Party of Hungary. Despite the broad palette of parties, there were only two basic ideological trends on the political landscape _ the populist nationalism of the center right, and more radical left-of-center liberalism. The conservative Democratic Forum lays considerable emphasis on Hungarian traditions and Christian values, which are also espoused by the smaller Hungarian Peoples' Party and the Christian Democratic Peoples' Party. Their strength lies largely in provincial towns outside Budapest. The Forum led slightly in the most recent Gallup poll from March 12, with 21 percent. Next strongest with 20.3 percent were the Free Democrats, a liberal party with social democratic leanings that wants to move Hungary quickly toward a Western-style society. There was no margin of error cited in the poll. Third in the poll with 15.7 percent of support of the 1,000 respondents, were the Independent Smallholders. Their main support is in rural Hungary, where they have pledged to return land taken by the Communists to its owners. The League of Young Democrats espouses views close to those of the Free Democrats and hopes to garner 10 percent of the vote.

DOC.HEAD: Six Florida Stations Pick Up Castro Speech
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 11th graf to CORRECT town to Donelson sted Donaldson
DOC.TEXT: A speech by Cuban President Fidel Castro that could be heard on radios as far away as North Carolina raised concern Saturday that ``the warning shot across the bow'' may have been fired in the battle over TV Marti. The Federal Communications Commission complained to Cuba about the broadcast over six AM frequencies, said spokeswoman Lorrie Secrest. TV Marti, the U.S.-financed television station, is expected to begin beaming programs to Cuba this month from a balloon over the Florida Keys in spite of Cuba's protests. Cuba regards the prospect of U.S. news shows, sitcoms and soap operas as a blatant intrusion on national sovereignty _ or ``tele-agression,'' as Castro calls it. In the midst of final preparations for the debut of TV Marti, Castro's Havana speech popped onto the airwaves Friday night, Ms. Secrest said. U.S. signals have been jammed many times in recent years, especially when the 5-year-old Radio Marti, the model for the TV station, was being debated in Congress. The Cuban government has threatened retaliation if the Bush administration went ahead with a 90-day test of TV Marti. Previous radio jamming from the communist nation has come at different times, frequencies and power levels. ``We are very vulnerable in the United States,'' said Susan Kraus, spokeswoman for the National Association for Broadcasters. ``We have to wonder if this is the warning shot across the bow preceding an all-out radio war.'' Of primary concern to U.S. broadcasters is Cuba's transmitting potential, including a 1 million-watt and two 500,000-watt transmitters. The highest power level allowed by FCC licenses is 50,000 watts. ``They have the capability of jamming AM stations in more than 30 states, all the way north to the Canadian border and all the way west to Utah,'' Kraus said Saturday in a telephone interview from Washington. ``They have demonstrated this in the past.'' Although stations as distant as Colorado have reported previous jamming, only two stations, WAMB in Donelson, Tenn. and WYRU in Red Springs, N.C., had filed complaints by late Saturday night, said Ms. Secrest. She said the FCC is following up on reports that the speech interfered with the signal of at least six AM stations south of Palm Beach. The Cuban Communist Party newspaper Granma mentioned Friday morning that Castro's remarks would be broadcast toward to United States on Friday evening, and the FCC picked up the broadcast at 9 p.m. EST. Castro, who has been holding fast against the reforms of the East Bloc, said in his speech that he recognized the socialist world has reached a delicate point but added, ``Capitalism hasn't solved the problems of Latin America.''

DOC.HEAD: Conservatives Concede Labor Likely to Prevail in Elections
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Bob Hawke said Sunday it appeared his Labor Party prevailed in parliamentary elections and his conservative opponent, Andrew Peacock, conceded a Labor victory was likely. Hawke, speaking a day after Saturday's vote, said he expected a one-seat majority in the 148-seat House of Representatives. He said a ``worst case scenario'' would give Labor 73 seats, and the conservative coalition 73, with two independents. Hawke, clearly surprised by the apparent tight outcome, said that when final results are in, ``I hope it may be a bit better than that (one seat). It will give a sense of discipline for sure and we can do it.'' Peacock, 51, would not concede defeat. But on Sunday, the leader of the Liberal and National Party coalition acknowledged Labor had a better chance of taking the election. ``If you are setting a book I suggest the shortest odds would be regrettably on a hung parliament, followed then by a Labor government just ahead of a possibility of a Coalition government,'' Peacock said in Melbourne. Peacock, who made his second bid for the prime ministership, emphasized, however, the outcome of six or seven seats in the states of Western Australia and Queensland still had not been decided. Vote counting, routinely suspended for Sunday, was to resume Monday. Political leaders said the results won't be known for sure until Thursday, when mail-in ballots are counted. Forty of 70 Senate seats were also contested Saturday, and early results showed the small Democratic Party made strong gains. The House, the more powerful chamber, chooses the prime minister. Communities with undecided races included the small town of Kennedy in northern Queensland, where several thousand voters were unable to cast their ballots because polling booths were cut off by floodwaters. Hawke, 60, has governed for seven years. He campaigned on his record of economic management, despite dissatisfaction over record home mortgage interest rates and a $100 billion foreign debt. Hawke said the 1990 election would set the course for Australian politics into the 21st century. Australia has 10.6 million eligible voters among its 16.5 million people, and voting is compulsory. When vote counting closed Saturday night, Labor appeared to have won 73 seats, the coalition 70 and the Independents two. The independents, the first elected in 24 years, could hold the balance of power in the House. Labor, which had 85 seats in the previous lower house, needs 75 seats for a working majority. Australia is a close U.S. ally, and President Bush said he hoped to visit the country before the year's end. Hawke came to power in 1983, was re-elected the following year and again in 1987. He has said that, if re-elected in this race, he will seek a fifth term before retiring.

DOC.HEAD: Anglican Spiritual Leader Announces Retirement
DOC.TEXT: The Most Rev. Robert Runcie said Sunday he will retire next January as archbishop of Canterbury, the leader of 70 million Anglicans worldwide. Runcie made the announcement during a morning service at Canterbury Cathedral marking the 10th anniversary of his enthronement, his London office said. Runcie offered his resignation to Queen Elizabeth II in her role as head of the Church of England, one of 27 self-governing churches within the Anglican Communion, which also includes 2.5 million U.S. Episcopalians. The Church of England requires its bishops to retire at age 70, but Runcie said he would step down on January 31, eight months before his 70th birthday on Oct. 2, 1991. The gap leaves time for Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher to appoint his successor. It is widely believed she will select someone whose social and economic views are more in tune with her own. Runcie, a liberal prelate, has often spoken against the policies of Mrs. Thatcher's governing Conservative Party. He preached forgiveness after Britain's victory over Argentina in the 1982 Falklands war, he supported coal miners during their 1984 strike, and in 1985 Runcie said the English church should contribute millions of dollars to relieve poverty and homelessness in Britain. ``I judge the beginning of 1991 to be the right time for me to hand over to the next archbishbop of Canterbury,'' Runcie said in a statement. ``The public announcement today will give sufficient time for the name of my successor to be known well before the end of this year. I ask for prayers in support of those responsible for making that choice.'' Runcie has been credited with holding his church together during controversy over the ordination of women bishops. About 1,200 women priests have been ordained by U.S. Episcopalians and Anglicans in Canada and New Zealand, but the Church of England still does not permit the ordination of women. Runcie's personal envoy, Terry Waite, is among 18 westerners held hostage in Lebanon. The longest-held is Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent of The Associated Press, kidnapped March 16, 1985. Waite was trying to negotiate the release of other hostages when he disappeared in Beirut in January 1987.

DOC.TEXT: A fire that swept through a packed social club in the Bronx borough early Sunday killed at least 87 people, fire officials said. The fire was reported at 3:41 a.m. in the one-story Happyland Social Club in the East Tremont section near the Bronx zoo, fire department spokesman Lee Rodriguez said. At least 100 people were caught in the 20-by-50 foot building when the fire broke out, according to local radio reports. Many of the deaths apparently were due to smoke inhalation. Assistant Fire Commissioner Robert Ungar said at least 87 bodies were found inside the heavily damaged club. More than 30 firefighters were fighting the blaze and removing survivors, Rodriguez said. An official of the Emergency Medical Services said some patients were taken to hospitals in Manhattan and the Bronx. A neighbor, Lilian Rivera, said the club was frequented by Dominican immigrants who live in the neighborhood. She said it was a ``family club'' during the day.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
New York City Social Club Fire Kills At Least 87
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with new quotes, injured man described as 'lone survivor,' adds background on previous fires, clarifies that it was worst fire in continental U.S., since Puerto Rico, site of 1986 fire that killed 96, is U.S. territory. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: A suspicious fire swept through a jam-packed, illegal social club for Latin immigrants in the Bronx early Sunday, killing at least 87 people, fire officials said. The fire, the worst in the continental United States in 13 years, was reported at the Happy Land Social Club near the Bronx Zoo at 3:41 a.m. and quickly spread through the two-story brick building. Authorities and witnesses said the panic-stricken victims were trapped and only one man apparently managed to escape, severely burned. ``This is the worst thing I have seen in my career. It hurt my stomach. It was sickening,'' said Emergency Medical Services specialist Christopher McCarthy. ``Most of the bodies were in dance clothes,'' he said. ``They were out to have fun. ... I saw wall-to-wall bodies _ an indication of mass confusion and panic.'' The blaze was brought under control by 6 a.m., said a fire department spokesman, Lee Rodriguez. Officials said the fire's rapid spread suggested an accelerant was used. ``That heavy volume of fire immediately arouses suspicion,'' said Assistant Fire Chief Robert Ungar. One witness heard what sounded like gunshots before the fire. But Unger would not comment on reports that there was a fight before the fire broke out or that gasoline cans were found at the scene. EMS Lt. Roy David said he got to the scene just a man believed to be the lone survivor, apparently the club's disc jockey, was staggering out. ``He walked toward me,'' David said. ``He couldn't talk. He couldn't say anything. All we could do was treat him.'' Another witness, Victor Perry, said: ``There were no people coming out. The DJ's clothes were stuck to his burnt skin which was coming off.'' The building received an eviction notice in January because of improper exits, and was in the process of being condemned, said Building Commissioner Charles Smith. ``The sad part of it is that this did not have to happen,'' said Mayor David Dinkins, who visited the scene a few hours after the fire. Many of an estimateed 700 similar clubs operating in New York City may be unsafe, and are being investigated, he said. A fire at another Bronx social club killed 25 people on Oct. 24, 1976. Ungar put the death toll at 87 or 88 people. A makeshift morgue was set up in the building next door, and relatives gathered at the scene. Authorities said the victims were mostly Latin immigrants, primarily Hondurans. Lynn Schulman, an EMS spokeswoman, said most of the victims died from smoke inhalation, but added, ``Some people were trampled.'' She said the survivor was a 25-year-old man who suffered second-and third-degree burns on his arms and legs and was taken to Jacobi Hospital in guarded condition. Five firefighters, including a battalion chief who broke his leg, were taken to Jacobi Hospital after inhaling smoke and at least six other firefighters were treated for minor smoke inhalation at the scene, she said. Perry said three sounds like gunshots were heard just prior to the fire in the building that housed the club, which was only 20 feet by 50 feet. Rosemary Green, whose sister-in-law and cousin were at the club, said she and other people were coming from a neighborhood birthday party and going to club when she encountered the scene. ``People were screaming. They were all burned. ... We're looking for friends and relatives and nobody's telling us anything,'' she said. ``Once you got in the entrance there was no way to get out.'' The building housed a group that organized children's baseball as well as adult socializing, said Lillian Rivera, a neighbor who lives across the street from the club. At least 30 firefighters from six companies were called to the scene, Rodriguez said. The fire was the deadliest in the continental United States since a May 28, 1977, blaze that consumed the Beverly Hills Supper Club in Southgate, Ky., killing 164 people. A Dec. 31, 1986, fire at a hotel in San Juan, Puerto Rico, a U.S. commonwealth, killed 96 people. Sunday's fire occurred on the 79th anniversary of one of New York City's worst fires, the Triangle Shirtwaist Co. blaze that killed 145 people, most of them immigrant workers. The fire led to reforms governing safety of the workplace.

DOC.HEAD: Gunmen Ambush Buses, Three Children Die
DOC.TEXT: Gunmen fired on two passenger buses in the central Philippines, killing three children and wounding 18 people, a mayor said Sunday. Renato Reyes, mayor of Bongabon, told radio station DZMM that the gunmen attacked the buses Saturday in the town located on the eastern coast of Mindoro island, about 130 miles southeast of Manila. Reyes said the gunmen might have been members of the New People's Army, which has been waging a 21-year insurgency to establish a Marxist state. He gave no reason for his suspicions. He said one of the wounded was a soldier and that government forces were pursuing the gunmen. The reason for the attack was unclear, but rebels and other armed groups have attacked buses in the past because their owners refused to pay protection money.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Ads Halted For Tourist Spot Known For Sex Offenses, Harassment
DOC.TEXT: The government will stop promoting the country's third most popular tourist spot because of widespread child prostitution and other problems there, a newspaper reported Sunday. Ads for Pagsanjan Falls, where parts of the movie Apocalypse Now was filmed, will be discontinued next month because of illicit activity and harassment of tourists, the Manila Chronicle quoted Tourism Undersecretary Rafael Alunan as saying. Alunan was quoted as saying officials tried to seek cooperation from local business groups but failed. The scenic falls and gorge, about 30 miles east of Manila, have drawn about 600 visitors daily since January, the newspaper said. It described the falls area as the third major tourist destination but did not name the other two. The area around the falls has become a center for child prostitution, and tourists have complained about boatmen gouging ferry prices, the newspaper said.

DOC.HEAD: 276 People Sentenced To Death For Drug Trafficking In 1980s
DOC.TEXT: The government said Sunday that it sentenced 276 people to death for drug trafficking during the 1980s and arrested more than 100,000 people for the offense during that period. Inspector-General Haniff Omar, in a speech quoted by the national news agency Bernama, also said the government sentenced 240 to life in prison for the offense. He did not say how many people actually were executed, but last month a 41-year-old Malaysian became the 82nd person to be hanged after being convicted under a tough 15-year-old law against marijuana, heroin and other drugs. Australians, Singaporeans, Filipinos, Thais, Indonesians and a Briton were also among those put to death under the law, which calls for the death penalty for anyone caught in possession of more than half an ounce of heroin. During the 1980s, a total of 101,268 people were arrested for various drug offenses, Haniff said. He gave no further details.

DOC.HEAD: 34 Killed, 800 Injured in Storm
DOC.TEXT: A storm that pounded most parts of the country during the past two days left at least 34 people dead and 800 others injured, police and news reports said Sunday. Power lines snapped, 4,000 mud-and-straw houses were blown away and thousands of acres of rice crops were uprooted in the storm that started Friday night, the reports said. Most houses in Bangladesh, a country of 110 million people, have mud walls and floors with roofs fashioned from thin mats of straw or split bamboo. Rice is the main food for the impoverished people of Bangladesh, one of the world's poorest with an annual per capita income of $160. Thousands of people are killed every year in Bangladesh in frequent natural disasters that range from droughts to floods, cyclones to hurricanes.

DOC.HEAD: Cells More Crowded Despite New Construction
DOC.TEXT: Local jails grew more crowded between 1983 and 1988 as new construction failed to keep pace with a 54 percent increase in the number of prisoners, the Justice Departmnt said Sunday. The size of housing space for each inmate shrunk 6 percent from 54.3 square feet in 1983 to 50.9 square feet in 1988 despite a 43.7 percent increase in total jail space, according to a study by the department's Bureau of Justice Statistics. A census of the nation's 3,316 jails found that on June 30, 1988 there were 341,636 prisoners living in 17.4 million square feet. Five years earlier, 223,272 inmates occupied 12.1 million square feet of living space. The bureau's study found that 28 percent of the nation's jails in 1988 housed more than 40 percent of their inmates in cells that were smaller than the recommended standard of 60 square feet. In 1983, only 23 percent of the jails housed inmates in cells that were smaller than the standard recommended by the American Correctional Association. The proportion of jails placing five or more people in a ``housing unit'' increased from 24 percent in 1983 to 28 percent in 1988, the study said, and the average occupancy rose from 2.4 inmates per unit to 2.5 inmates. In 1988, 61 percent of all jail inmates lived in the most crowded facilities. Local jails hired an additional 29,000 guards _ a 65 percent increase _ during this period, reducing the ratio of inmates per guard from 5.0 in 1983 to 4.6 in 1988. Jails in New Jersey were the most cramped _ averaging 39.6 square feet per inmate. The most spacious jails were in North Dakota, where the average inmate had 88.8 square feet of living space. Eight other states had jails with cells that were smaller than the national average of 50.9 square feet. They were: Virginia, 40.4; Tennessee, 42.3; California, 43.0; Louisiana, 43.1; Georgia, 43.9; Texas, 44.0; Massachusetts, 49.0, and South Carolina, 49.6. Besides North Dakota, the largest living spaces for inmates were in Montana, 76.7 square feet per inmate; Wyoming, 76.1; Iowa, 75.6; Nevada, 70.5; Idaho, 69.9; Minnesota, 66.8, and Maine, 65.5. The rest of the states surveyed had jails with an average cell size exceeding 50.9 square feet per inmate. The study included all locally run facilities for holding defendants after arraignment in 44 states and the District of Columbia. Temporary holding cells and lockups were not included in the study. Connecticut, Delaware, Hawaii, Rhode Island, and Vermont were not included in the study because they have combined jail-prison systems. Alaska's prison-jail system was also not included, but five separate local jails in the state were included.

DOC.HEAD: India's Departure Offers New Chance for Peace _ or More War
DOC.TEXT: A 42-year-old rift between Sri Lanka's Sinhalese majority and Tamil minority begins a new and possibly less hostile chapter this week with the end of India's pendulum-like intervention in the conflict. The last Indian soldiers left Sri Lanka's northeastern shores Saturday, ending a 2{-year jungle war against the Tamil guerrillas they once trained. Now the Sinhalese-dominated government and Tamils seeking an independent nation are reassessing their traditional antagonism. Both sides want to build on the tenuous peace they forged last summer, a peace that grew out of mutual opposition to the Indian presence. But the durability of their new-found understanding is being questioned. ``I am afraid the peace will break down once the convergence of their aims ends,'' a Western diplomat said on condition of anonymity. ``And the convergence ends when the last Indian soldier steps on a ship for home.'' The Tamil-Sinhalese discord, simmering since Sri Lanka became independent from Britain in 1948, spawned a Tamil insurgency in 1983. It also fueled an uprising against the government in 1987 by ultranationalist Sinhalese who objected to peace overtures made to the Tamils. The twin wars have killed at least 17,000 people and brought this tropical island, once famed as a sun-and-sand holiday destination, to the brink of anarchy. In the Tamil-dominated north and east, the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam and other Tamil groups launched a guerrilla war, first against the Sri Lankan army and then against the Indian peacekeepers. Sinhalese radicals and government forces were locked in a grisly battle in the south and center of the island. Every morning they left bodies of victims in remote villages and along the coastal highway. The Sinhalese uprising came to a virtual halt in December after most radical leaders were killed by Sri Lankan security forces. On the Tamil front, the militants and the government reached a rare understanding: Both wanted Indian forces off the island. ``We are both against foreign occupation armies,'' Ajit Mahataya, the Tigers' second-in-command, told The Island, a Colombo newspaper. ``This may have helped build up trust that has allowed us to negotiate seriously.'' India, encouraged by its own Tamil minority, became involved in the Tamil war for an independent nation soon after it began in 1983. Most Tamil rebel groups, including the Tigers, were based in the southern Indian city of Madras and were trained in military camps in India. When the Sri Lankan army stepped up repression against the Tamils in 1987, India tried to pressure Colombo into calling a cease-fire. The pressure tactics worked _ but with a twist. The Sri Lankan government agreed to give the Tamils limited autonomy but said Indian soldiers must enforce a surrender of arms by the guerrillas. India, acting on behalf of the Tamils, signed a peace pact with Sri Lanka on July 29, 1987. Two months later the Tigers repudiated the agreement, claiming they were not consulted, and turned their guns on the Indians. Soon, India was fighting a full-scale war, at one point pitching as many as 125,000 soldiers against an estimated 2,000 Tiger guerrillas and countless part-time fighters. At least 1,155 Indian soldiers and about 2,000 Tigers were killed in battle. Last summer, Sri Lanka demanded the Indians leave. The new government, headed by President Ranasinghe Premadasa, said it could handle the Tamil insurrection. After initial hesitation, India agreed to go. ``We are leaving with at least part of our job done,'' an Indian diplomat said on condition of anonymity. ``We may not have got an A-plus, but we did not get a C-minus either. We are leaving Sri Lanka a united nation, and that is a tremendous achievement considering the situation in 1987.'' Some analysts believe the Sinhalese-Tamil unity will last. ``The government of Sri Lanka does not want to go back to square one,'' said Neelan Tiruchelvam, a Tamil political analyst. ``Another confrontation will destroy the nation state.'' At the root of the problem is the Tigers' demand for independence, which they have not renounced despite the truce with Colombo. Talks center on what kind of power the Tigers will exercise. Government officials say Tamil areas will form a loose federal state with considerable local autonomy. ``The answer is somewhere between a totally independent state and the kind of provincial power we have now,'' said Bradman Weerakoon, President Premadasa's top adviser. ``I see a superb chance for coming to terms,'' Weerakoon, a Sinhalese, said. ``Previous governments had not completely realized that there were some areas that could be perceived as being discriminatory to the Tamils. This president realizes that Tamil demands have some kind of basis.'' Tamils claim discrimination by the Sinhalese, who form 75 percent of the country's 16 million people and control the government, military and most employment opportunities. Sinhalese say the Tamils, who comprise 18 percent of the population, hold jobs and wealth disproportionate to their numbers. Premadasa's efforts to ease ethnic tensions have struck a chord among the Tigers, but they say they are prepared to return to the jungle. ``We are giving him all the opportunities we can,'' Stanley Dominic, a senior guerrilla, said from the northern Tiger-held town of Jaffna. ``If he doesn't use them properly and as a result there is another war, we are prepared for it.''

DOC.HEAD: Brother of Pol Pot Cannot Fathom Evil of Communist Revolutiontary
DOC.TEXT: Saloth Suong devoted his life to Cambodian Buddhism and royal tradition. His brother tried to eradicate both, and stands accused of slaughtering 3.3 million compatriots. Saloth Suong's brother is Saloth Sar, alias Pol Pot, whose primitive Communist revolution ranks in savagery with Adolf Hitler's holocaust and the mass purges of Soviet dictator Josef Stalin. Saloth Suong, 78, says he is unsure what drove his younger brother to impose the reign of terror whose victims included members of their own family. He does not want to see his brother again, either for a personal reunion or as head of the Khmer Rouge guerrillas Pol Pot is said to still lead. ``But I am not afraid if they come. I am too old already for fear,'' he said. ``I pray often at the pagoda.'' His 71-year-old wife, Chea Samy, is less fatalistic. The most prominent mistress of Cambodian classical dance, she works to preserve the art as a teacher at the Fine Arts University. In one of the many tragic ironies of the couple's lives, it was Pol Pot who tried to stamp out the exquisite dance along with other, centuries-old cultural legacies. ``If they came back they would destroy it again, so I must teach and document as much as possible,'' she said, sitting beside her husband in their spartan rooms in a decrepit apartment block. Saloth Suong bears a striking resemblance to his infamous brother. He has the same stocky build, fleshy cheeks and high forehead, and he says the two were close as boys and young men. ``Saloth Sar was a very polite, gentle boy. He respected the old people and they liked him,'' his brother said. ``I have no idea why he became so evil. I keep wondering about that. Maybe it was the things he studied and the friends who influenced him.'' Pol Pot's father is said to have been a land-owning farmer of good standing. A cousin who married into the royal family took some of the nine children, including Pol Pot and Saloth Suong, to Phnom Penh for studies. Through the cousin, Pol Pot is distantly related to Prince Norodom Sihanouk, the former Cambodian leader imprisoned by Pol Pot and now chief of the uneasy guerrilla alliance fighting Phnom Penh's Vietnamese-backed government. The U.S.-backed resistance includes the Khmer Rouge. Saloth Suong says Pol Pot lived with him for years. Chea Samy bought him food, washed his clothes and helped him with life in the capital. The cousin connected to the Cambodian royalty proved a ``second mother.'' With a scholarship in hand, Pol Pot left to study radio electronics in Paris in 1949 but failed his exams. Much of his time was reportedly spent talking leftist politics with fellow Cambodians; some historians say the Khmer Rouge was born on Paris' Left Bank. Saloth Suong says he saw his brother for the last time in the early 1960s. Sihanouk's police were hunting for the fledgling revolutionary, who fled to the jungle to help organize the ultra-radical movement he would soon dominate. For years, Saloth Suong thought his brother had been killed. Saloth Suong's own career was spent within the Royal Palace, as an administrator, protocol official and personal assistant to Sihanouk's mother, Queen Kossamak. Sihanouk was toppled in 1970 and the ensuing five-year war ended with a Khmer Rouge victory. Saloth Suong, a brother and sister were forced into agrarian communes, along with the entire population. The brother died of hunger and illness and Pol Pot's ``second mother'' starved to death. Saloth Suong and Chea Samy say they labored from 5 a.m. to 7 p.m. He cut logs for firewood, she washed 700 dishes daily in a communal kitchen. Illness sapped their strength. In late 1978, while cleaning the communal kitchen, Saloth Sar watched workers putting up a photograph of the shadowy Khmer Rouge leader, who had discarded his real name for that of Pol Pot. ``At first I didn't recognize him. But some people noted the resemblance and told me that Pol Pot was Saloth Sar,'' he said, recalling his feeling of anger. ``People asked me: `Why don't you go to Pol Pot. He is a big man.' But I told them he was not really a brother to me, so I could not come to him.'' Vietnamese forces overthrew the Khmer Rouge in late 1978. The government has said the regime killed 3.3 million people in executions, famine and civil unrest. Other estimates are lower but still astounding given Cambodia's 1975 population of about 8 million. After the new government was installed in early 1979, Saloth Suong and his wife returned to Phnom Penh and his brother fled back to the jungle. Despite his announced retirement in 1985, Pol Pot is believed to still lead the Khmer Rouge. Vietnam said it withdrew all its troops from Cambodia last year, leaving the government led by Prime Minister Hun Sen to fight the resistance. Saloth Suong lives quietly and works part-time as a keeper of artistic property at the Ministry of Culture. Late last year he returned to his native village for a reunion with three surviving siblings. There was a Buddhist ceremony of gratitude and remembrance of dead family members. The village temple, traditional center of rural life, had been turned into a hospital by the Khmer Rouge, its images smashed, its monks derobed. Asked if they were shunned because of their brother, Saloth Suong laughed gently. ``Not at all,'' he said. ``The villagers welcomed us with warmth because they knew we too had suffered under Pol Pot.''

DOC.HEAD: Deformed Woman Who Fought For Child Custody Now Battling For Boardwalk Space
DOC.TEXT: A legless, armless woman who won custody of her daughter 14 years ago by changing the baby's diaper with her teeth now plays ``We Shall Overcome'' and ``Over The Rainbow'' on this city's Boardwalk by pressing her tongue against a keyboard. However, her music strikes the wrong chord with municipal prosecutor Steve Smoger, who said Celestine Tate is a ``con artist'' taking advantage of a special permit given her by the city by not living up to an agreement to pay a fine in exchange for being allowed to perform. Ms. Tate, a 34-year-old mother of two who lives in Ventnor, said during a break from a recent performance in front of Bally's Park Place Casino Hotel that she just wants to play her music. ``It's a nice way to occupy my time rather than just sitting around doing nothing,'' Ms. Tate said in a singsong voice. She frequently asks God to bless passers-by who drop quarters and dollar bills into the bucket in front of her hospital gurney. Smoger estimates Ms. Tate earns from $120,000 to $140,000 a year. Ms. Tate puts the figure at more like $70,000 to $80,000. She said her two daughters _ ages 11 and 14 _ attend private school in Philadelphia, and that she has to pay her $750-a-month rent plus the expenses of a woman who comes in to help her at a weekly cost of $158. In 1976, Ms. Tate had to prove to a Philadelphia judge that she could care for the first of those girls after the welfare department said she lacked the ability to raise the child. ``I changed her diaper in court and the judge gave her back to me,'' Ms. Tate said, adding the child's paternal grandmother forced her to break up with the girl's father because she was disabled. ``It was the Lord's will that I give birth to her so it must be his will that I have her.'' Ms. Tate was born in Philadelphia suffering from birth defects that left her legs and arms undeveloped. During the interview, she had to ask her cousin to pull a blue blanket over her when the wind blew off the Atlantic Ocean onto the Boardwalk. ``God gave me ways to use my mouth that people with hands can't,'' she said. ``I wouldn't trade me with anybody.'' Ms. Tate reaches the Boardwalk spot with the help of a cousin, who pushes her gurney two miles from Ventnor. She said she likes to pass the Boardwalk's rolling chairs en route. ``I'll be saying, `Beep, beep,' when I pass them,'' said Ms. Tate, who laughs and smiles easily, raising her eyes from her keyboard to see whomever she is talking with. She learned her craft in Philadelphia at a music school for the disabled and came five years ago to Atlantic City, a tourist destination she remembered as a child and wanted to return to as an adult. Tourists and residents alike seem to gravitate toward her, filling her bucket as if it it were a wishing well with requests guaranteed. ``I think it's beautiful,'' said Millie Vixson after she floated a $1 bill into the bucket. ``I admire the idea.'' Ms. Tate, who is about 4 feet tall and weighs about 170 pounds, has had to battle repeatedly to preserve a spot on the Boardwalk and make a living, and her battles may not be over. In March 1989, the city gave Ms. Tate a special permit that exempted her from the city's 80-year-old ordinance barring Boardwalk panhandling. As part of the agreement, Municipal Judge Bruce Weekes said she had to pay a $2,600 fine over the next year for 26 violations. That followed a similar agreement reached in November 1986 between her and city officials. Smoger said she has reneged on her latest agreement. Ms. Tate freely acknowleges she hasn't paid the fines, arguing that since that she's not a beggar she shouldn't have to pay them. She said she is not worried about possible further legal action against her. ``You're going to lock me up and feed me in jail or I'm going to eat on my own,'' Ms. Tate said. Smoger said he sympathizes with Ms. Tate's disability but grows tired of sparring with her over her failure to pay the outstanding fines. ``She has done a remarkable job and should be commended for elevating herself to the position she has,'' Smoger said. ``She's a con artist. Every benefit that could be bestowed on to her has been bestowed by the city of Atlantic City.'' He said he will seek revocation of her license if she does not pay the full $2,600 when her license comes up for its yearly renewal in June. Smoger defended the anti-begging ordinance as necessary to prevent the Boardwalk from being swamped with people asking for money. Ms. Tate said she's an entertainer, not a beggar or a public nuisance. ``I could not be begging with my mouth full,'' she said. Her latest court battle involves something different than her freedom to make a living. She is scheduled for a hearing in Egg Harbor Township municipal court Friday on marijuana possession charges. Ms. Tate said she is innocent. Howard Mitchell, Ms. Tate's cousin and the most recent relative to push her gurney down the Boardwalk and watch over her, said he has faith in the woman he calls ``Teeny.'' ``I get up and run away from life when I get scared,'' Mitchell said. ``She keeps my spirit very high. Sometimes I'll just say `Teeny, thank you.'''

DOC.HEAD: VA Benefits Review Sends Veterans' Groups to the Battlements
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUBS 11th graf pvs, bgng: The report, to DELETE extraneous material
DOC.TEXT: Disclosure that the Veterans Affairs Department is reviewing its $12 billion benefits program has caused more scrambling than a battle alert among veterans advocates. The ``enemy'' _ real or imagined _ won't be known until the VA issues its proposals in the next six weeks. Still, veterans groups are upset because VA began the review without telling them and didn't announce it until the Disabled American Veterans obtained internal VA documents and revealed their existence at a congressional hearing Feb. 27. The American Legion says the disclosure has set back relations with veterans service organizations that had begun to improve with the elevation last year of the VA to cabinet level and the appointment of a new VA chief. ``It angers me that the department ... is looking for ways to eliminate certain benefits, particularly when these deliberations have been carried out without the knowledge of those who serve as consumer advocates for veterans,'' Legion Commander Miles S. Epling said in a letter March 8 to VA Secretary Edward J. Derwinski. VA says it is only trying to make the system more fair, that savings would be plowed back into the financially strapped health care system, and Congress would have to approve any modifications. Furthermore, VA says, there would be increases in benefits as well as decreases, and any cuts would apply only to future veterans. ``I think they should wait until we put a package on the table,'' said Deputy Secretary Anthony J. Principi, who is leading the benefits review. But try telling that to organizations representing the nation's 27 million military veterans. Tinkering with Social Security could be easier. The VA pays $12 billion a year to 2.2 million veterans, 310,000 widows or widowers, and 1 million dependents or spouses to compensate for disabilities and death. The review follows a General Accounting Office study last July that said VA paid $1.7 billion in 1986 to compensate for diseases that arose during military service ``but were neither caused nor aggravated'' by service. The report said Congress ``may wish to reconsider'' whether eight diseases should be considered as service-connected and eligible for compensation: arteriosclerotic heart disease, diabetes, bronchitis and emphysema, arthritis, hemorrhoids, multiple sclerosis, uterine fibroids and Crohn's Disease. Congress did nothing. ``It's not a sacred cow and we'll look at it some day in the future,'' said Rep. G.V. ``Sonny'' Montgomery, the Mississippi Democrat who chairs the House Veterans Affairs Committee, The VA is considering the GAO recommendations, although Principi says the internal review would have been undertaken regardless. VA says cost-cutting recommendations are balanced by ones to make it possible for a veteran to be declared 100 percent disabled after 10 years instead of 20 years; for mentally ill veterans to retain benefits while trying to enter the job market; and by paying a flat compensation rate for surviving spouses. Veterans organizations say they became suspicious of the VA because of it did not challenge the GAO's conclusions more forcefully. ``VA is not required to examine the nature of certain diseases or to determine a causal connection to military service,'' Derwinski told GAO in a letter that was part of the report. F. David Parker, president of the Paralyzed Veterans of America, said, ``We will never accept the argument that veterans who served 24 hours every day, always on call, while on active duty in every corner of the world, should not be compensated for a disability that was not the result of an actual military duty.'' The veterans groups say VA is resurrecting proposals made by groups more interested in slashing the budget than in helping veterans. They say VA had been discussing such proposals as eliminating cost-of-living payments for people with 10 percent to 20 percent disability ratings, or even eliminating payments for people in those lower disability ratings, and means testing for certain payments. ``I think we blew their scenario,'' said John Heilman, legislative director of the Disabled American Veterans. He said that without DAV's intervention, VA would have acted behind the scenes. Heilman's group and the PVA claim Principi is carrying out the agenda of Sen. Alan K. Simpson, R-Wyo., former head of the Senate Veterans Affairs Committee and a critic of the benefits system. Principi formerly was a top aide to Simpson, who urged his Senate colleagues in a letter March 7 ``to keep an open mind and not be sucked in by the hysterical hype of these professional fundraising veterans.'' Principi says there was no secrecy involved. Many proposals were rejected early in the process, he said, and the VA wanted to settle on a group of proposals before releasing them.

DOC.HEAD: Breast X-Ray Use Increases Sharply, Survey Says
DOC.NOTE: Eds: For release at 6 p.m. EST.
DOC.TEXT: The share of doctors who use breast X-rays to look for cancer in symptom-free women has doubled to nearly 100 percent in five years, marking a milestone in early cancer detection, the president of the American Cancer Society said Sunday. Ninety-six percent of physicians said last year they used mammograms to screen symptom-free women at least some of the time, compared with 49 percent in a 1984 survey, said Dr. Robert Schweitzer. While that does not mean all women are receiving the mammograms as often as the cancer society recommends, the trend is ``an important milestone in the road toward that goal,'' Schweitzer said. The percentage of doctors who said they met or exceeded the cancer society's recommended mammogram guidelines tripled, from 11 percent in 1984 to 37 percent in 1989. Schweitzer discussed the survey findings at a science writers conference sponsored by the cancer society. Under the society's guidelines, a woman with no symptoms of breast cancer should get a mammogram between ages 35 and 39, a test that serves as a ``baseline'' for comparison in future tests. Women 40 to 49 should have a breast X-ray every one to two years, depending on physical condition and previous mammogram results, and those age 50 and over should have one every year. Mammograms and other cancer screening tests are aimed at finding cancer in its early stages, when it is more curable. The physician survey was commissioned by the cancer society. It covered 1,029 general and family practitioners, internists and obstetricians and gynecologists. Results were weighted so that the percentages would reflect all doctors in those specialties now practicing in the continental United States. The margin of error was generally plus or minus 2 percent to 3 percent. Sixty-one percent of physicians said they were giving greater emphasis to early breast cancer detection in symptom-free patients than they had five years ago. In 1984, 39 percent had said they were giving it increased emphasis. Forty-four percent said they were putting greater emphasis specifically on mammograms last year, compared with 14 percent in 1984. The survey also found that the number of doctors who check for blood in the stool, a potential sign of colorectal cancer, rose from 75 percent in 1984 to 89 percent in 1989. Schweitzer said the only screening test not reported to be widely used was proctosigmoidoscopy, in which a tube-shaped device is used for inspecting the colon. Forty-nine percent of doctors reported using that test last year, up from 35 percent in 1984. Only 23 percent of physicians said last year that they followed or exceeded cancer society guidelines for the test, which the society recommends every three to five years in symptom-free persons age 50 and over. Forty-one percent of doctors said they use chest X-rays to screen symptom-free patients, a practice the cancer society does not recommend.

DOC.HEAD: GOP Chairman Released From Hospital
DOC.TEXT: Republican National Chairman Lee Atwater was released from the hospital Sunday after physicians adjusted the medication he is taking for a brain tumor, an aide said. Atwater, 39, underwent a radiation treatment Saturday at George Washington University Hospital after being admitted on Friday, complaining of queasiness, said Leslie Goodman, a spokeswoman for the Republican National Committee. ``He's home and is in good spirits again,'' Ms. Goodman said Sunday. ``He said he was feeling fine.'' A small, non-malignant tumor was discovered earlier this month on the ride side of Atwater's brain after he collapsed during a speech and was rushed to the hospital. He is taking radiation treatments five days a week to reduce the tumor. Atwater was named head of the RNC after managing George Bush's presidential campaign in 1988.

DOC.HEAD: Agent Orange Study Expected This Week
DOC.TEXT: Government scientists are expected to release a study this week that will help determine officially whether Vietnam veterans who were exposed to the herbicide Agent Orange suffered cancers and other ailments as a result. The study by the federal Centers for Disease Control, which the Veterans Affairs Department says will be released Thursday, examines the incidence of five kinds of cancer among Vietnam vets. It is another step in a 12-year battle to gain benefits for veterans who blame cancers, skin disease and miscarriages in their spouses on the powerful foliage killer. VA Secretary Edward J. Derwinski last November said he would put off a determination on whether to award benefits until after the study was completed. Following its release, the study must be reviewed by a VA advisory committee of outside scientists. Derwinski will make a determination at the end of May after the committee meets, VA spokesman Don Smith said last week. Final rules should be in place in October. The decision also could influence legislation in the House and Senate requiring compensation to veterans. Derwinski said in a recent interview that the decision on Agent Orange will be the most difficult he's made since becoming the first VA secretary a year ago. ``The advice is so terribly conflicting,'' he said. ``There's no consensus out there.'' Nearly 35,000 claims have been filed citing Agent Orange as a cause of disabilities. An additional 230,000 veterans have told VA they were exposed to the herbicide, which contained highly toxic dioxin and other suspected harmful ingredients. The new Selected Cancers Study by the CDC in Atlanta does not look at whether veterans were exposed to Agent Orange, which was sprayed to remove foliage and kill crops. According to the VA, the new study will determine whether Vietnam veterans are at higher risk of developing soft-tissue sarcoma, lymphoma and nasal, nasopharyngeal and liver cancer. The study began in 1985. CDC spokesman Chuck Fallis said he could not confirm that the study would be released Thursday, the day given by the VA and the American Legion. VA says the study can be combined with other studies, mostly dealing with the exposure of industrial and farm workers to dioxin, to tilt the balance one way or the other regarding a possible connection to disorders. The Legion, however, is telling veterans not to hold their breaths. ``The government has ducked the issue of Agent Orange for more than a dozen years,'' National Commander Miles S. Epling said. ``We are tired of waiting for more studies, especially irrelevant ones.'' The Legion contends the CDC scuttled an earlier attempt at a study by saying no reliable sample of veterans can be found. The Legion says CDC has ignored detailed military records of troop movements and spraying activities that could produce such a study group. A Legion study claims to have established a connection between Agent Orange and skin rashes and blisters, fatty tissue tumors, hypersensitivity of the eyes to light, and an increased risk of miscarriages among spouses. The Legion says the study was too limited to reach further conclusions regarding other cancers. VA says scientific advisers to Congress and the administration have rejected the Legion study because it relied on questionnaires filled out by the veterans themselves. The Agent Orange issue was revived last May when U.S. District Judge Thelton E. Henderson said VA had used too rigid a standard _ cause and effect between exposure and disease _ in evaluating Agent Orange studies. Derwinski decided not to appeal Henderson's order that the VA need only find a ``significant statistical association'' between exposure and disease before determining to award compensation. The VA's outside Environmental Hazards Advisory Committee met in November to review about 30 studies dealing with herbicide exposure and its relation to non-Hodgkins lymphoma using the new criteria. The group said it could neither find nor rule out a significant statistical association, giving little guidance to Derwinski. Derwinski said afterward he would wait for the new CDC study. He cited remarks by members of the committee that such a study would be useful.

DOC.HEAD: Hawke Confident Of Fourth Term, Peacock Concedes That Is Likely
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Bob Hawke's conservative challenger said incomplete election returns Sunday indicated he was likely to fail in his attempt to block Hawke from serving a record fourth consecutive term. Hawke, who has governed for seven years, said he and his Labor Party expected to stay in power with a one-vote majority in the 148-seat House of Representatives after Saturday's balloting. Andrew Peacock, the opposition leader of the Liberal and National Party Coalition, acknowledged Labor probably had the numbers in parliament. ``If you are setting a book I suggest the shortest odds would be regrettably on a hung parliament, followed then by a Labor government just ahead of a possibility of a Coalition government,'' Peacock told reporters in Melbourne. When counting was halted Saturday night, Labor appeared to have won 73 seats, the coalition 70 and the Independents two. Labor, which had 85 seats in the previous lower house, needs 75 seats for a working majority. There was no further counting Sunday, and the earliest results were expected Monday. The final outcome may not be known until Thursday, when mail-in ballots are counted. Hawke, 60, told a news conference early Sunday that he will continue in a caretaker capacity and that he expected to form a government that would keep him in power for another three-year term. Hawke, clearly surprised by the close election, said that when final results are in he expected a one-vote majority but added: ``I hope it may be a bit better than that.'' Australia's sagging economy had been the focus of a largely uneventful five-week campaign during which Peacock told the country's 10.6 million voters that Hawke's policies could lead to a recession. Peacock criticized the government for record 18 percent mortgage rates and a $100 billion foreign debt in this nation of 16.5 million. Peacock, who at 51 had made his second bid for the prime ministership, said he would continue planning for the transition of government because the outcome of six or seven seats in the states of Western Australia and Queensland still had not been decided. Political pundits had said Peacock's political career hung in the balance, with defeat likely to lead to him being dumped as leader of the Liberal Party. He said his coalition could pick up several of the doubtful seats, which includes the small town of Kennedy in northern Queensland, where several thousand voters were unable to cast their ballots because polling booths were cut off by floodwaters. Hawke came to power in 1983, was re-elected the following year and again in 1987. He has said that if re-elected in this race, he will seek a fifth term before retiring.

DOC.HEAD: Extra Police Sent to Kosovo, Government Insists No Poison Found
DOC.TEXT: Troops dispersed hundreds of demonstrators in Kosovo province Sunday after the government accused Albanian nationalists of causing a mysterious illness that sickened hundreds of ethnic Albanian teen-agers. The republic of Serbia, which assumed direct control of police in the southern province Saturday, sent 2,500 police reinforcements to maintain law and order, Radio Belgrade reported. Sreten Lukic, chief of Serbia's police force in Kosovo, announced a purge of ethnic Albanian policemen who allegedly did nothing to protect Serbs from attacks last week, the Belgrade daily Politika Ekspres reported. Police Sunday morning dispersed 2,000 members of Kosovo's ethnic Albanian majority demonstrating near Titova Mitrovica, 24 miles north of the provincial capital, Pristina. Ethnic Albanians also reportedly manned occasional roadblocks, checking drivers' papers in the poor, rugged province bordering Albania. At Urosevac, 18 miles south of Pristina, about 800 Serbs and Montenegrins from Kosovo's Slav minority rallied to demand that police confiscate weapons from all ethnic Albanians, Radio Belgrade said. Nearly 1,000 schoolchildren, most of them members of Kosovo's ethnic Albanian majority, were hospitalized last week, complaining of lung and other complaints and alleging they were poisoned by a mysterious gas. At least one Serb policeman and one Serb schoolgirl also reportedly sought treatment in Titova Mitrovica, north of Pristina, for the illness. A Yugoslav Health Ministry Friday dismissed claims of poisoning, but ethnic Albanian leaders in Kosovo claimed their investigations were biased. Late Saturday, the federal government announced that the mystifying incident was ``an action of Albanian separatists'' intended to stir more unrest in Kosovo. ``Evidently, this involved a planned action by Albanian extremist nationalists designed to ... spark further deepening of nationalist skirmishes with possible tragic consequences,'' the government said, according to the official news agency Tanjug. Military authorities say no trace of poison has been found among the victims, and in the statement the government did not say what it thought the illness was or how it was caused. More than 60 people have died in ethnic violence in the past year in the province, which is administratively part of Serbia. Ninety percent of its population are ethnic Albanians seeking to regain autonomy lost last year when Serbia assumed direct control of Kosovo's judiciary and schools. Serbia, the largest of Yugoslavia's six republics, argued this was necessary to protect the Slav minority in Kosovo, the cradle of Serbia's medieval kingdom.

DOC.HEAD: Pro-Democracy Groups Rally in Mongolian Capital
With AM-Lithuania, Bjt
LaserPhoto ULB1
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of pro-democracy demonstrators gathered in the capital's central square Sunday to demand democratic reforms, including an end to government funding for the ruling Communist Party. Speakers also demanded the abolition of party cells in ministries and schools. Some of the 7,000 people in the square carried banners reading, ``Democracy is our gun,'' and ``National Unity.'' The speakers, who stood in a truck-bed rigged with loudspeakers, said they invited Communist Party officials to make speeches, but none accepted. The Communist Party, formally called the Mongolian People's Revolutionary Party, receives about 20 million tugriks a year, or $6.6 million at the official rate. New political parties that plan to challenge the Communists in upcoming elections receive no funding and lack money for offices and basic equipment. Demonstrations began in Mongolia in December as Communist governments throughout the Soviet bloc began to give way to democratic movements. Protesters in Mongolia have won a complete shake-up of top party and government ranks, and promises of free elections. But the opposition claims that in talks with the Communist Party authorites have reneged on their promises. The opposition halted those talks last week, claiming that the government representatives were changed each time talks were held and lacked the authority to reach agreemenmts. ``We will go back if it will be televised live and ... have real decision-making power,'' said I. Javkhlant, leader of the Mongolian Democratic Association, one of the opposition groups. If not, he said his group will resort to more aggressive tactics. He did not elaborate. It is unclear whether the government will legalize all of the new opposition groups. A top legislative official indicated Saturday that only socialist parties would be permitted. Mongolia has been a satellite of Moscow since Soviet troops helped it win independence from China in 1921. But many Mongolians resent the presence of about 60,000 Soviet soldiers and some 50,000 civilian experts and dependents. Moscow plans to withdraw its troops by 1992, and has called home some of the civilians. At Sunday's rally the crowd gave some of its loudest cheers to a journalist, Dogoodorg, who interviewed former dictator Yumjaagiyn Tsedenbal in February for the first time since his 1984 ouster. Like many Mongolians, Dogoodorg uses only one name. The interview, aired Saturday night on Mongolian television, saw the now-feeble Tsedenbal defend decades of harsh rule. ``The authoritarian system has its positive side,'' Tsedenbal, 73, said from his Moscow home. He insisted party officials purged in the 1960s were Chinese spies. His Soviet wife, Anastasia, tried repeatedly to stop the interview, shouting at the reporter and stepping in front of the camera.

DOC.HEAD: Idaho's Restrictive Abortion Bill Puts Governor At Center Stage
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Cecil Andrus, who once pushed for jailing women and doctors who participated in abortions, now must decide the fate of another bill that would ban almost all abortions through civil rather than criminal sanctions. The decision puts the three-term Democrat at the center one of the most divisive issues the country has seen since the Vietnam War.
