Within the next three weeks, he will either approve or veto the most restrictive state abortion law. Andrus refuses to discuss his intentions for the bill that would ban more than 90 percent of the 1,500 abortions performed in Idaho each year. The Idaho Legislature on Thursday gave final approval to a bill to ban abortions as a means of birth control, allowing them only in cases of non-statutory rape reported within seven days, incest if the victim is younger than 18, severe fetal deformity or threat to the mother's life or health. Women who violate the provisions would not face sanctions, but the physicians involved could face fines up to $10,000 for a first offense. On the night of the vote, at a party Andrus gave for Democratic lawmakers, he made a few non-committal jokes about the decision awaiting him. But his quip about just leaving town and letting the Republican lieutenant governor handle the bill indicated his wariness of the issue. In the days before that, however, Andrus vehemently reaffirmed his longstanding opposition to abortion except in the case of rape, incest and the life of the woman. ``Let there be no doubt in anyone's mind as to Cecil Andrus' position on abortion,'' the governor said when he announced for re-election just days before the Senate sent him the bill. ``I have always opposed legalized abortion,'' said Andrus, who is Lutheran. ``My views haven't changed.'' The bill headed to his desk is the one the National Right to Life Committee wants to test the U.S. Supreme Court's commitment to legalized abortion. It would seem to fit the criteria set by Andrus. Seventeen years ago, in his first term as governor, he signed legislation in the wake of the Roe vs. Wade decision that would _ if the Supreme Court decision is ever overturned _ ban all abortions except to save the woman's life and imprison the women and doctors involved. A leading opponent of the abortion restrictions, Democratic Sen. Marti Calabretta, said the discussions he's had with Andrus in the past ``haven't led me to believe he will do anything different.'' Still, in making his decision, the governor is also juggling economic and political considerations in the midst of his bid for an unprecedented fourth term as chief executive. Party leaders hoping to attract pro-choice voters in the fall have been pressuring him to veto the bill that 14 of the 19 Democratic senators and 13 of the 21 Democratic House members voted against. ``It would be damaging for him,'' Sen. Karl Brooks said, citing public opinion polls showing that while a majority of Idahoans oppose abortion even more oppose government intervention in the decision. ``He would be out of touch with the party he's in and the state he governs,'' Brooks said. ``That's bad politics.'' But at age 58 with 30 years of public service under his belt both in Idaho and in the Cabinet under Jimmy Carter, Andrus is anything but bad at politics. As Carter's interior secretary in 1980, he successfully guided the Alaska Lands bill through a national debate to create America's largest wilderness. Eighteen months ago, he stared down the federal government he once served to end its use of his state as a temporary storage dump for radioactive waste. A one-time logging and mill worker, Andrus served three terms in the state Senate before making his first, and only unsuccessful, race for governor in 1966. Andrus is a heavy favorite this year to become the state's first four-term governor. His only announced Republican opponent in the pro-choice camp is Boise stockbroker Milton Erhart, a political novice. The likely GOP nominee _ state Sen. Rachel Gilbert of Boise _ backed the anti-abortion bill. Andrus has reportedly been pressured by some of his major contributors on the potential negative economic impact of the restrictive abortion law that critics claim would drive doctors out of a state already seriously short of rural medical care. There have also been threats by abortion rights supporters in other states that if the bill is not vetoed they will boycott Idaho's No. 1 commodity, potatoes. But the independent governor has bristled at threats in the past, and the latest controversy does not seemed to have changed that. On the eve of the abortion bill's final approval, he told one supporter who was lobbying him for a veto, ``If you make this one issue your determination of whether you support me after 30 years, I don't want your support.''

DOC.HEAD: Anglican Leader Announces Retirement
LaserPhoto LON1
DOC.TEXT: The archbishop of Canterbury, the Most Rev. Robert Runcie, announced Sunday he will resign as leader of the world's 70 million Anglicans next Jan. 31. Runcie said his ``chief hope'' before retiring was to be reunited with his envoy, Terry Waite, one of the 18 westerners held hostage in Lebanon. Waite disappeared in Beirut three years ago while trying to negotiate the release of other hostages. ``My thoughts are very much that we shall be united again,'' Runcie told reporters. ``That's what I pray for before I lay down this office.'' Runcie tendered his resignation a few weeks ago to Queen Elizabeth II, the temporal head of the state Church of England, said his spokeswoman, Eve Keatley. He delayed making a public announcement until Sunday's morning service at Canterbury Cathedral in southeast England marking the 10th anniversary of his enthronement as the 102nd successor to St. Augustine. The archbishop of Canterbury is spiritual leader of the Church of England, and 26 other self-governing churches which make up the Anglican Communion, including the 2.5 million-member U.S. Episcopal Church. The Church of England requires its bishops to retire at age 70, but Runcie's planned departure date falls eight months before his 70th birthday. In a statement Runcie said his early announcement is intended to give Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher time to appoint his successor later this year. ``I am resigning now because it is 10 years and I think it is time to leave and hand over to somebody else,'' Runcie told reporters. Mrs. Thatcher will select the new archbishop from a list of two candidates drawn up by a committee of senior churchmen. She will then make her recommendation to the queen who will make the formal appointment. Speculation about possible successors has touched on most of England's senior bishops as well as Archbishop Robin Eames, head of the Anglican Church in Ireland. Mrs. Thatcher has consulted him in the past about Northern Ireland. The Sunday Telegraph, a conservative weekly which has rebuked the archbishop in the past, said Runcie would be difficult to replace: ``There seems little prospect of finding anyone who would do this impossible job any better; partly, it is because he is a genuinely decent person, intelligent, witty and lacking in pomposity; in a bureaucratic institution full of self-important and ruthless men.'' It is widely expected that Mrs. Thatcher will want to appoint someone more in step with her conservative views. Runcie had frequently been at odds with Mrs. Thatcher's government, preaching forgiveness for Argentina after the Falkland Islands War in 1982 and offering moral support to striking miners during their bitter yearlong strike. He urged that more be done for the homeless and for decaying inner cities, and last year he said Britain was in danger of becoming a nation of ``pharisees.'' Pharisees were members of an ancient Jewish party who were denounced by Jesus Christ for self-righteousness and hypocrisy. Runcie has been credited with holding his church together during a time of falling attendance and a divisive debate over the ordination of women bishops. Women priests have been ordained by U.S. Episcopalians and Anglicans in Canada and New Zealand, but are still not permitted by the Church of England. Runcie was born into a working class family which he described as not particularly religious. He won a scholarship to study at Oxford University and fought in World War II as a tank commander where he was decorated for bravery. Church historians say he was the first primate to have fought for his country since the Middle Ages. Runcie said it was the horrors of the battlefield that inspired him to enter the priesthood in 1951. Mrs. Keatley said Runcie and his wife, Rosalind, a concert pianist, would retire to St. Albans, 19 miles northwest of London, where they recently bought a home. Runcie told reporters he planned to spend his retirement reading, watching cricket and spending time with his family.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS last item to CORRECT name to `Friz,' sted `Fritz.'
DOC.TEXT: At age 83, Friz Freleng, the man who helped create a stable of Warner Bros. cartoon characters, could have long ago said, ``That's all folks!'' and retired. But Freleng is still busy tickling America's funny bone. Freleng was honored by about 60 cartoon buffs Saturday at a reception sponsored by the Kansas City Museum in conjunction with a cartoon animation exhibit. Freleng, a Kansas City native, said his latest project is a pilot television series starring one of his most popular characters, the Pink Panther. He is on the Warner payroll as an adviser to the pilot, which he said CBS hopes to launch this fall. The combination live action and animated show revolves around a police officer and his feline companion, the Pink Panther. Freleng directed 266 cartoons for Warner Bros. after being recruited to Hollywood by his former Kansas City employer, Walt Disney. Among his creations were Porky Pig, named after two chubby childhood playmates; Yosemite Sam; Sylvester the Cat; Tweety Bird; and Speedy Gonzales. He was among those who contributed to the creation of Bugs Bunny and Daffy Duck. ``I enjoy all of them,'' Freleng said. ``I guess the most popular one is Bugs Bunny.''

DOC.HEAD: Tanzanian Intellectuals, Party Leaders Back Socialism
DOC.TEXT: Bucking the trend of multiparty reform in other parts of the world, intellectuals and officials in this socialist country ended a three-day conference Sunday by agreeing to keep their one-party system. Intellectuals and party officials, however, acknowledged that recent events in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union carried a message for their East African country. Rather than allowing a multiparty system, the participants agreed, Tanzania should reform its single party to permit greater participation and end corruption. Walter Bgoya, general manager of the Tanzania Publishing House, said the experience of Eastern Europe showed only the death of Stalinism, not of socialism. Stalinism, he said, was characterized by a cult of personality and secrecy in government. He urged Tanzania's government to open itself to public scrutiny. The symposium was called to explore the effects of changes in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union on Tanzania, which has had a socialist one-party system of government since independence from U.N. trusteeship in 1961.

DOC.HEAD: Pope Urges Negotiated Settlement in Lithuania
DOC.TEXT: Pope John Paul II on Sunday appealed for ``sincere dialogue'' to find a just and peaceful solution to the standoff over heavily Catholic Lithuania's declaration of independence from the Soviet Union. In his first public comments on Lithuania since its March 11 independence declaration, the pope referred to the ``Lithuanian nation'' and emphasized its centuries-old ties with the Vatican. However, John Paul stopped short of recognizing the independence declaration. Observers said the pope is reluctant to jeopardize the Vatican's newly forged diplomatic ties with Moscow. In Denmark, the government urged an international condemnation of the Soviet Union for its attempts to cut off Lithuania from the rest of the world, news reports said Sunday. The Soviet ambassador in Copenhagen was called to the Foreign Ministry to receive an official protest note, the reports said. In Washington, President Bush's national security adviser, Brent Scowcroft, said Saturday that any Soviet use of force or intimidation in Lithuania ``would be counterproductive'' to U.S.-Soviet relations. Scowcroft said the Bush administration would take appropriate measures in response to what it considered excessive Soviet pressure or an increase in tensions in the Baltic republic. He did not elaborate but said military action was not a likely option. Moscow has sent tanks rumbling through Lithuania's capital in what legislators there regard as an attempt by the Red Army to intimidate them so they will reconsider their declaration of independence. The Soviet Foreign Ministry also ordered foreign diplomats, including two Americans, out of Lithuania and said foreign journalists would no longer be allowed to travel to the Baltic republic. Lithuania, an independent country before World War II, is of special interest to the pope because it is the Roman Catholic stronghold in the Soviet Union. An estimated 2.5 million people, or 80 percent of Lithuania's population, are Roman Catholics. The Vatican has never recognized the Soviet annexation of Lithuania, and there is a Lithuanian diplomatic mission accredited to the Holy See. ``Today Lithuania finds itself at the center of interest of Europe and the world,'' the pope said in his Sunday noon Angelus from his balcony overlooking St. Peter's Square. ``Let us pray to divine providence so that the Lithuanian question finds a just and peaceful solution through sincere dialogue and in the framework of the international order.'' ``May God give light and strength to all all those upon whom this resolution depends,'' he said, speaking in Italian. John Paul, who has often expressed the wish to visit his flock in Lithuania, noted that he was twice refused permission to make the trip: in 1984 for celebrations marking the 500th anniversary of the death of Lithuania's patron saint, Casimir, and in 1986 for the 600th anniversary of the evangelization of the area. Monsignor Algimantas Bartkus, rector of the Pontifical Lithuanian College in Rome, hailed the pope's remarks. ``This spiritual and moral solidarity and support gives us the strength we need at this moment,'' he said in a telephone interview. Lithuania has posed a delicate situation for the Vatican, which only 10 days ago established diplomatic ties with Moscow for the first time since the 1917 Russian Revolution. Bartkus said he understands that the pope does not want to offend the Kremlin by openly endorsing Lithuania's independence. ``We cannot ask for too much,'' he said. ``The Holy Father has always shown very special attention to Lithuania, and we know he is on our side.'' The situation of the church in Lithuania has improved substantially under Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. But Lithuanian Cardinal Vincentas Sladkevicius recently told the Catholic weekly Il Sabato that the church is ``not yet free'' and that Lithuania should be independent. Gorbachev has invited the pope to visit the Soviet Union, but the cardinal said he hopes John Paul will travel to Lithuania separately, perhaps at the time of his trip to Poland in June 1991. ``Lithuania is ready for the Holy Father,'' Bartkus said. ``His visit would probably be the biggest event of the century for Lithuania.''

DOC.HEAD: Artillery Duels in Christian Heartland Kill 2
DOC.TEXT: Rival Christian forces fought with howitzers, tank cannons and rocket launchers on mountaintops northeast of Beirut on Sunday, and police said three people were killed and five wounded. The artillery battle, and an earlier one on Saturday, threatened a cease-fire agreement that brought months of fighting to ahalt on March 3. Police said the latest battle began at daybreak and raged past noon in the highlands of Kesrouan Province, pitting troops of maverick Gen. Michel Aoun against the Lebanese Forces militia of Christian warlord Samir Geagea. Both sides blamed each other for the fighting, which police feared could lead to another all-out battle for control of Lebanon's Christian enclave. The enclave includes 310 squares miles north and northeast of Beirut. ``The truce is fraying. It will definitely collapse if the accelerating tempo of violations is not arrested,'' a police spokesman said. He said three civilians were killed and five people, including two militiamen, wounded in the exchanges. That raised the overall toll since Jan. 30, when Aoun moved against Geagea, to 768 dead and 2,129 injured. The fighting underlined the failure of neutral Christian mediators to work out a political settlement to resolve the power struggle. The March 3 cease-fire was negotiated by a three-man Christian mediation committee. Shaker Abu Suleiman, spokesman for the committee, accused Aoun and Geagea of ``issuing shooting orders while claiming a sincere quest for peace. He said the committee, which is supported by the Vatican, demanded that the fighting be stopped and negotiations resumed to achieve a ``durable political settlement under no security pressure by any side.'' A Lebanese Forces communique said Aoun's gunners blasted its positions in the summer resort towns of Rayfoun, Feytroun, Ajaltoun and Ghosta with sustained barrages of tank cannons and 155mm howitzers. Aoun's command said its forces opened up only after their positions in pine-forested towns of Bekfaya and Ein Tuffaha came under rocket fire from 40-tube launchers of the Lebanese Forces. Police said a pair of Israeli jet fighters, apparently sent to film the fighting, streaked over the Kesrouan mountains in supersonic runs. Sonic booms echoed through the capital. Israel's air force regularly patrols Lebanese air space, mainly to monitor movements of Yasser Arafat's Palestinian guerrillas in south Lebanon and Syrian troops stationed in and around Beirut. On Friday night and Saturday, Aoun's 19,000-strong army and Geagea's 6,000-strong militia fought 16 hours of artillery battles in Kesrouan that killed three people and wounded eight. Patriarch Nasrallah Sfeir, spiritual head of the dominant Maronite Catholic sect to which both Aoun and Geagea belong, appealed for an end to the fighting. ``The army and the Lebanese Forces must promptly withdraw back to their barracks,'' Sfeir said in a Sunday sermon at the chapel of his patriarchal seat in Bkirki on the Kesrouan coastline, 20 miles north of Beirut. ``Have mercy on the people. Stop shooting. Halt this alarming exodus of Christians,'' Sfeir said, referring to the flight of hundreds of thousands of Christians from the enclave. ``Do not finish off the Christians while pretending to defend their interests.'' Sfeir urged the remaining Christians to ``rebel in a public uprising that will force your tormentors to end the war.''

DOC.HEAD: Brazil's Economic Plan Creates Furor Over Civil Liberties
DOC.TEXT: Brazil's new economic plan has led to the arrest of about 30 businessmen and bankers for ``economic crimes'' and a police raid on a company that publishes a book describing tax shelters. Several of the arrested businessmen have been held in jail for days, without being charged and without a bail hearing. Some have been detained in cells containing people suspected of committing violent crimes. The incidents, critics say, show that President Fernando Collor de Mello's new economic measures have resulted in serious civil liberties violations. ``We are heading for a dictatorship. The arrests are a flagrant violation of rights consecrated in the constitution,'' legal scholar Gofredo de Silva Telles said in a television interview. Marcio Tomaz Bastos, former president of the Brazilian Bar Association, told The Associated Press: ``The new law is a violence. If you kill someone you can respond to the charge at liberty. But if you raise the price of a beer you can be jailed for months without trial.'' Collor announced his economic plan on March 16, one day after taking office as Brazil's first popularly elected president in 29 years. He passed the package using ``provisional measures,'' which became law immediately but can be voted down by Congress within 30 days. Brazil's Supreme Court is due to hear arguments on Wednesday regarding the legality of the ``economic crime'' portion of the plan. The measures, designed to bring down record inflation that reached 2,700 percent in the past year, include a 30-day price freeze, a new national currency, and a freeze on assets of more than the equivalent of $1,200 from private savings accounts and $600 from short-term money market deposits. The freeze withdrew an estimated $115 billion from circulation, about 80 percent af all bank deposits. Also included was a controversial provisional measure that subjects managers and owners of companies that commit ``crimes against the popular economy'' to two-to-four-year jail terms. The law does not provide suspects with the right to apply for bail between the time they are arrested and tried. In the 10 days since the plan was passed, at least 30 businessmen and bankers have been arrested and charged with violating the new law, according to newspaper and television reports. Last week, Antonio Gaspar, manager of an Eldorado supermarket was arrested in Sao Paulo, Brazil's biggest city, and charged with economic abuses, the most serious being increasing the price of some fish by 500 percent. On Friday, four members of the prominent Verissimo family, which owns the Eldorado chain, were arrested in connection with the case. Those charged were placed under house arrest and presumably will be tried later. Several bank managers in major cities have also been arrested and jeered by crowds as they were led away by police. The managers were charged with denying clients the right to withdraw up to the legal maximum from their bank accounts. Public opinion polls show the economic plan has overwhelming public support. One survey, by the Brazilian Institute of Public Opinion and Statistics, the nation's leading polling outfit, found that 94 percent of the people supported jail time for economic crimes. The company interviewed 2,250 people in Brazil's eight largest cities. No margin of error was provided. Several of the arrested businessmen have been held in jail for days, some in cells containing people charged with violent crimes. Others accused of committing economic crimes have been freed on their own recognizance. Police raided the Tama publishing house in Rio on March 19, seized copies of the book ``Tax Havens,'' which describes various tax shelters, and charged two of the company's officials with ``inciting tax evasion.'' Brazil's 1988 constitution prohibits all censorship. Four days later, the offices of Folha da Manha, which publishes the prominent Folha de Sao Paulo newspaper, were raided by heavily armed federal police agents who arrested two company officers for allegedly post-dating an invoice to avoid the currency freeze. The newspaper has been critical of Collor, publishing a number of reports during last year's presidential campaign that accused him of corruption during his 1987 to mid-1989 term as governor of the northeastern state of Alagoas. The paper's owner believes the police action was no coincidence. ``Not even during the dictatorship were we victims of violence like that,'' Folha de Sao Paulo's owner, Octavio Frias, told the newsweekly Veja, referring to Brazil's 1964 to 1985 right-wing military regime. Rep. Renan Calheiros, congressional leader of Collor's National Reconstructuion Party, also criticized the raid on Folha de Sao Paulo. However, he denied it was an attempt to silence the newspaper. He defended the law against economic crimes and the need for ``coercive measures so people don't undermine the economic plan.'' But others see the raid on the newspaper as part of an ominous trend that is a natural consequence of the government's law against economic crimes. ``As with the previous case of the Tama officials, I foresee the federal police, with its new powers, being transformed into an organ of repression,'' said Barbosa Lima Sobrinho, head of the Brazilian Press Association.

DOC.HEAD: Minnesota Gets Little Support in Asserting Control Over Guard
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUBS 2nd graf pvs, bgng: The justices, to include that Perpich is governor; and SUBS 5th graf pvs, bgng: It was, to DELETE extraneous word `policy'
DOC.TEXT: Only six other states are supporting Minnesota's contention before the Supreme Court that control of National Guard training missions is a states' rights issue. The justices are scheduled to hear oral arguments Tuesday on a suit by Minnesota Gov. Rudy Perpich challenging the constitutionality of a 1986 law enacted in reaction to opposition from some Democratic governors to former President Ronald Reagan's Central American policies. Perpich contends the Montgomery Amendment named after Rep. G.V. ``Sonny'' Montgomery, D-Miss., violates the militia clause of the Constitution because it denies governors authority to control the peacetime training of National Guard units. The amendment specifically bars governors from withholding consent to a National Guard unit serving on active duty outside the country because they don't like the location, purpose or schedule of the mission. It was enacted after several governors said they opposed the Reagan administration's policies in Central America and did not want National Guard units from their states assigned to train in the region. Officials from 29 states, including 19 governors, have filed briefs with the court supporting the Montgomery law. The Supreme Court last year rejected hearing a similar challenge to it by Massachusetts officials. Perpich, a Democrat, has not viewed the question as a foreign policy matter but as one of states' rights. ``The Montgomery Amendment is an unnecessary federal power grab that violates an unambiguous command in the text of the United States Constitution,'' Minnesota officials said in their brief to the court. ``The plain meaning of the militia training clause cannot be more evident. The authority of training the National Guard is reserved to the states.'' Massachusetts and five other states _ Iowa, Maine, Montana, Ohio and Vermont _ have filed a brief supporting Minnesota's contention. Represented by their attorneys general, the states wrote the Supreme Court that the founding fathers intended for states to control the militia to prevent abuses by the federal government. ``There is no doubt that state control over the militia was an integral part of the framers' planned structure as a means of securing the blessings of liberty won in the war of independence,'' according to those states. However, the governors of 19 states and attorneys general for 10 more states contend in their own brief filed with the Supreme Court that Perpich ``is seeking to arrogate to himself a role in foreign affairs.'' The 8th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals ruled in June that the Montgomery Amendment is constitutional, saying that the state's power to organize militias ``cannot constrain Congress' authority to train the guard as it sees fit.'' In Minnesota's view, Justice Department lawyers contend, Congress could require National Guard units to fight overseas without the authority to train them properly. American forces have fought in tropical climates nothing like Minnesota's nearly every time they've been sent into battle over the past 20 years, Rep. Bill Frenzel, R-Minn., and 23 other members of Congress said in a brief supporting the administration's position. ``No longer are the militia, if mobilized, likely to fight in their own states defending their own territory,'' the lawmakers said. The National Guard has been under dual state and federal control since Congress made it a component of the Army in 1933. Enlistees enroll simultaneously in the state militia and a reserve unit of the U.S. armed forces. The Army National Guard now provides 46 percent of the Army's combat units and 28 percent of its support forces. And the Air National Guard now represents 73 percent of the nation's interceptor forces, 25 percent of its tactical fighters and 24 percent of its tactical air support. States whose governors signed the brief in opposition to Perpich's suit are Delaware, Florida, Georgia, Idaho, Illinois, Iowa, Kansas, Louisiana, Maryland, Mississippi, Nevada, New Mexico, North Carolina, North Dakota, Oklahoma, South Carolina, Texas, West Virginia and Wisconsin. The 23 states whose attorneys general signed the brief are Alabama, Alaska, Delaware, Florida, Georgia, Idaho, Indiana, Kansas, Louisiana, Maryland, Mississippi, Missouri, Nevada, New Mexico, North Carolina, Oklahoma, South Carolina, South Dakota, Tennessee, Utah, Virginia, Wisconsin and Wyoming.

DOC.HEAD: CIA Ingored His Request on Watergate, Nixon Writes
DOC.TEXT: Former President Richard M. Nixon says in a new book that he made the ``inexcusable error'' of asking the CIA to block an FBI probe of the Watergate break-in but that the CIA declined. Nixon said a decision by then CIA Director Richard Helms and his deputy, Vernon Walters, to ignore the request discredits Watergate's ``most serious myth _ the one that ultimately forced me to resign:'' that the CIA in fact obstructed the FBI probe on his specific orders. In addition, Nixon writes in ``In the Arena,'' his new book excerpted in the latest issue of Time magazine, he later ``emphatically'' told FBI Director Patrick Gray to go forward with the investigation. Nixon said he made the request to the CIA on the recommendations of staff members who ``had a personal stake in covering up the facts.'' Nonetheless, in an interview with the magazine accompanying the book excerpts, Nixon said he expects historians to judge him more by Watergate than by his diplomatic overtures to China. ``Historians are more likely to lead with `He resigned the office,''' Nixon said in the interview. ``The jury has already come in, and there's nothing that's going to change it. There's no appeal. Historians will judge it harshly.'' In the book, Nixon writes that ``the most widely believed myth was that I ordered massive illegal wiretapping and surveillance of political opponents, members of the House and Senate, and news media reporters. All of these charges are false.'' Another misconception, he writes, was that he ordered the break-in at the Democratic National Committee. ``Not one piece of evidence was discovered indicating that I ordered the break-in, knew about the plans for the wiretapping ore received any information from it,'' he writes. Nixon also denies paying for any cover-up. ``It is clear that I considered paying the money,'' he says, referring to the famous taped conversation he had on March 21, 1973 with White House counsel John Dean. But Nixon adds that he later ruled out payments. Nixon, however, does not directly address in the Watergate section of the book a key aspect of the ``smoking gun'' tape in which he and White House Chief of Staff H. R. Haldeman discussed the FBI investigation. That tape, recorded June 23, 1972, six days after the Watergate break-in, contradicted Nixon's previous statements that he did not know of White House involvement in the Watergate coverup until the March 1973 conversation with Dean. ``Here was the `smoking pistol' the investigators had been looking for _ the direct, undeniable evidence that from the very beginning Nixon had been in on, had approved, had condoned and supported the attempt to bury the Watergate mess,'' U.S. District Judge John J. Sirica later wrote in his memoirs. Attempting to debunk what he calls ``the myths of Watergate,'' Nixon writes that ``others in my campaign and in my Administration attempted to cover up'' the connection between the burglary and his re-election campaign. ``I failed to take matters firmly into my own hands and discover the facts and to fire any and all people involved or implicated in the break-in,'' he says. On a more personal note, the ex-president says that following his near-fatal attack of phlebitis shortly after his resignation in August 1974, ``I could see no reason to live, no cause to fight for.'' But he recovered physically, spiritually and mentally, he says, because of strong support from his family and a circle of devoted friends and through writing his memoirs.

DOC.HEAD: Foreign Minister Criticizes End of Flights For Soviet Jews
DOC.TEXT: Hungary's Foreign Minister Sunday criticized the state airline for suspending flights of Soviet Jews to Israel after it received terrorist threats from pro-Iranian extremists. The state airline Malev suspended flights Wednesday and appealed to the Soviet airline Aeroflot to stop bringing Jewish emigres to Hungary. The Soviets announced Friday they would comply. Both suspensions followed threats by the Lebanese-based Islamic Jihad for the Liberation of Palestine against airlines that help fly Soviet Jews to Israel. Hungary's Foreign Minister Gyula Horn said Malev's decision to suspend the flights was made without prior consultation with the government. He called the suspension ``a rush decision'' and added that bowing to threats could encourage terrorism. Malev chief executive officer Lajos Jahoda told the Hungarian daily Mai Nap the decision was taken to protect passengers and Malev employees. ``We had to take the threats seriously because we consider safety a priority,'' he was quoted as saying. Budapest was the main transit station for Soviet Jews immigrating to Israel. The Soviet Union does not have direct flights to Israel and transit stations including Vienna and Bucharest are used. Israel's highest-ranking official on East European Affairs, Foreign Ministry Assistant Director-General Yosef Govrin, flew to Hungary Sunday to ask Hungary to reconsider its decision, a foreign ministry official in Jerusalem said. Israel's Foreign Minister Moshe Arens was quoted by the Hungarian state news agency MTI Saturday as saying Israel hoped that ``Hungary, which has just become a democracy, will not give an example for surrendering to terrorism.'' The Polish National Airlines Lot and Israel's El Al airlines were expected to provide an alternatate route for immigrants by adding two weekly flights between Warsaw and Tel Aviv, a Lot official in Tel Aviv said. Israeli officials claimed no knowledge of the move, which was reported on the front pages of three major daily newspapers. El Al spokesman Nachman Kleinman denied special arrangements were made to increase flights but noted that Lot and El Al have a standing agreement to add flights as demand warrants. Arab nations have criticized the wave of immigration, partly out of concern that some newcomers may settle in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. Israel has banned publication of Soviet immigration figures, but before censorship was imposed the government said 16,700 arrived between January 1989 and Feb. 1, 1990. According to The New York Times, some 6,000 are expected this month. It is estimated that 200 Soviet Jewish immigrants have settled in the occupied territories. Almost 750,000 Soviet Jews are expected to immigrate this decade following a relaxation in Soviet restrictions and increased wariness about growing expressions of anti-Semitism in the Soviet Union.

DOC.HEAD: Syria-Egypt Summit Caps Reconciliation
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: Talks in Libya between presidents Hosni Mubarak of Egypt and Hafez Assad of Syria sealed the end of a 12-year rift, bringing diplomatic gains for both countries. The history of relations between Syria and Egypt is a stormy one. The two countries were joined for three years as the United Arab Republic with Egypt's Gamal Abdel Nasser as head of state, but the union broke down in 1961. The one-hour Assad-Mubarak meeting took place late Saturday during a ceremony at Tobruk marking the 20th anniversary of the expulsion of British forces from Libya. It followed a resumption of diplomatic relations last December. Ties were broken a month after the late Egyptian president, Anwar Sadat, flew to Jerusalem in 1977 to begin the process that led to the Camp David peace treaty two years later, the only such pact between Israel and an Arab country. ``In one sense, it's a defeat for Syria,'' said a Western diplomat in Damascus. Like other foreign observers, he attributed the move largely to Assad's desire to escape from diplomatic isolation after Egypt was readmitted to the Arab League last May and other Arab nations resumed diplomatic ties. But the diplomat, who like other sources in Damascus insisted on anonymity, said the move also presented opportunities for the 59-year-old Syrian president to persuade fellow Arab leaders to follow his firm line toward Israel. By meeting Mubarak, Assad has shown once again that he is a master of maneuver in the Arab world, limiting his losses by joining the Arab mainstream without abandoning his cherished hard-line policies, diplomats said. For Mubarak, the reconciliation with Assad is a big payoff for his cautious policy of acting as a go-between. He has been working with Israel, the United States and the Palestinians on the one hand while trying to improve Cairo's relations with other Arab nations on the other. Syria is the most implacable enemy of the Jewish state and Assad has vowed to continue building up his forces until he reaches ``strategic parity'' with Israel so the Arab world can negotiate from a position of strength. But the Soviet Union, preoccupied with internal affairs and economic problems, has told Syria the parity concept is no longer tenable and said Damascus, a major Soviet client, should purchase only the weapons it needs for defense. Syrian and Soviet military leaders have agreed to the withdrawal from Syria of an undisclosed number of Soviet military instructors, an informed Syrian source said. Meanwhile, ties between the Soviet Union and Israel have slowly improved. The two countries have set up modest representation in each other's capitals and are exchanging low-level visits. Earlier this month Assad expressed his dismay, saying the changes sweeping Eastern Europe were a boon to Israel as the formerly Communist countries dropped their hostility to the Jewish state. Syria also is at odds with Palestine Liberation Organization leader Yasser Arafat and has rejected his peace initiative toward Israel, which is strongly backed by Egypt and the United States. There is no sign yet that Assad is cutting support for Damascus-based, anti-Arafat radical Palestinian factions which have been fostering relations with Iran _ just in case. But Assad appears to want inclusion, at least indirectly, in the current process involving Egypt, the PLO, the United States and Israel aimed at holding elections leading to some autonomy for Palestinians in Israeli-occupied Arab territories. Former President Jimmy Carter said after a meeting with Assad earlier this month that Syria is ready for bilateral talks with Israel if they include the Golan Heights, taken by Israel from Syria after the 1967 war. Egyptian officials in Cairo said they expect better but still limited relations with Syria in view of Egypt's close ties with Iraq, Syria's arch-rival in the Arab world. A meeting between Assad and Mubarak after December's resumption of diplomatic ties was originally expected to take place in Syria. There were several Syrian reports of an imminent Damascus meeting. But Mubarak never showed up, perhaps unwilling to be seen as knocking on Assad's door, perhaps fearing resentment by Iraq. Diplomats in Damascus said the Egyptian president would like to act as a matchmaker between Assad and Iraqi President Saddam Hussein. But given the deep hostility between two of the Arab world's most ruthless and ambitious leaders, there were no signs that there will be an opportunity for reconciliation. Intensifying the feud between the Iraqi and Syrian wings of the Arab Baath Socialist Party, ruling in both countries, Baghdad has supplied weapons to Lebanon's anti-Syrian Christian leader, Gen. Michel Aoun, thwarting Assad's effort to impose a pax Syriana on its war-torn neighbor. Syria was the only major Arab country to side with Persian Iran in its war against Arab Iraq.
EDITOR'S NOTE: Martin Marris is based in Cyprus and has covered the Middle East for The Associated Press since 1986.

DOC.HEAD: Record Holdup in Switzerland Nets $26 Million
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with more details on the theft, CORRECTS surname of police spokesman. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Four armed robbers raided a bank in downtown Geneva on Sunday and got away with the equivalent of $26 million. The haul was believed to be the largest in Swiss history, police said. The robbers confronted two security guards at the personnel entrance around 8 a.m. and forced them to turn over the keys of the main branch office of the Union Bank of Switzerland, police spokesman Marcel Vaudroz said. The thieves then entered the branch and emptied various safe-deposit boxes, driving off with 400 pounds of banknotes of various currencies. The spokesmen said the men had somehow obtained the keys or codes they needed to open the boxes they robbed. ``It was a well-prepared job and done by professionals,'' he said. Vaudroz said one of the two guards was treated at a hospital for injuries suffered when he was struck with a rifle butt. The gunmen, described as between 35 and 50 years old and fluent French speakers, remained at large, despite a large-scale manhunt.

DOC.HEAD: Lithuanians See Test of Perestroika in Gorbachev's Policy
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: Despite Mikhail S. Gorbachev's show of force and barrage of demands, Lithuanians keep assuring themselves the Soviet president will not use force to crush their independence because his reform program would die with it. ``It would be the end of perestroika and Gorbachev's policy and his authority,'' said Lithuanian Premier Kazimiera Prunskiene. ``I don't think Gorbachev would take such a measure.'' Western diplomats and political figures agree. ``It would undermine his policy in Europe, end perestroika and probably not even be successful,'' said one high-ranking diplomat in Moscow. In an era of reform, Soviet soldiers might refuse to use force against Lithuanians, the diplomat said. In the past week, tanks and armored personnel carriers have rumbled through the Lithuanian capital Vilnius, and Gorbachev has issued a flurry of directives to Lithuanians, including a demand that they turn in all their firearms and stop signing up for volunteer service. Soviet media have painted the Lithuanian government that declared independence March 11 as pushing the republic either toward anarchy or political repression. In an interview printed Sunday, Gen. Valentin I. Varennikov, commander of Soviet ground forces, charged that independence leaders were preparing to jail Communists. But the streets of the Lithuanian capital have been calm throughout the political tension, and citizens interviewed on the streets have expressed few fears of pending military action. Gorbachev and his advisers have said they do not intend to use force in Lithuania. Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze, a close adviser to Gorbachev, told reporters during his trip to Africa last week that the Soviet Union is ``particularly against the use of force domestically.'' But Gorbachev has pledged to keep the Soviet Union together, and he has been unable to bend the Lithuanians with argument and political pressure. His tough reaction to the declaration of independence has added caution to the Lithuanians' confidence that he won't use force. The Lithuanian government on Thursday night appealed to the world to speak out against any possible use of force by Soviet soldiers, and early Saturday passed a resolution transferring power to a longtime diplomat of independent Lithuania in Washington if the government is detained. The Soviet Union ``is accustomed to solving its problems, externally and internally, with the use of force,'' said Algimantas Cekuolis, who until independence was declared served as a legislator in the Soviet parliament. Lithuanian officials and Western diplomats say Gorbachev would risk wrecking his opening to the West, including the nearly completed agreements on slashing nuclear weapons by 50 percent and the removal of hundreds of thousands of troops from front lines in central Europe. Sen. Edward M. Kennedy, arriving in Moscow on Sunday, said use of force would put Gorbachev's relationship with the United States at risk. ``Any resolution of the issue other than through discussions would have very significant and damaging implications for that relationship,'' said Kennedy, D-Mass. On Thursday, the U.S. Senate passed a resolution 93-0 urging the Soviet Union to stop intimidating Lithuanians and warning that use of military force ``would have severe repercussions for U.S.-Soviet relatons.'' ``If he uses force in the Baltics, he can't maintain his current worldwide standing,'' Prunskiene said, ``and relations between the Soviet Union and other states could not remain the way they have been until now.'' A violent reaction also likely would cut the flow of foreign investment so desperately needed by the Soviet Union's collapsing economy. Kremlin officials last week for the first time hinted that the economy is in such bad shape that it might need outright foreign aid similar to the Marshall Plan that helped Germany recover after World War II. Western credits were temporarily suspended to China after that country cracked down on pro-democracy demonstrators in Tiananmen Square. Foreign businessmen, who had been increasingly disenchanted with China because of growing economic problems, have been reluctant to return because of uncertainty about the country's stability. Use of force also would cause a ferocious debate within the Soviet Union, such as the assault by soldiers on peaceful demonstrators in the capital of the Georgian republic Tbilisi last April. Nineteen people were killed, and one was shot later for violating curfew. Angry hard-liners want some sort of crackdown on secessionists, but reformers have thrown their support to Lithuania's parliament. The army also might not be totally reliable, if Gorbachev decided to use it in Lithuania. In January, Soviet mothers took to the streets to protest the mobilization of their sons to restore order in Azerbaijan, a Caucasus mountain republic engaged in a bitter dispute with neighboring Armenia. Soviet officials quickly backed down and ended the mobilization. Weighing the costs and benefits leaves Lithuanians wondering: Why the war of nerves? At worst, they worry Gorbachev is preparing the ground for armed intervention. At the least, he is forcing Lithuania residents, from the police to everyone owning a hunting gun, to take sides publicly and at personal risk. Still, there is hope the issue will be solved peacefully. ``If Gorbachev lets them go freely, they'll be so grateful that they will put up his statue instead of Lenin's,'' said Bill Hough, an American expert on international law concerning annexation and is in Vilnius advising the Lithuanian government.
EDITOR'S NOTE: Ann Imse has reported on events in the Soviet Union, including the three Baltic republics' drive for independence, since September 1988.

DOC.HEAD: Earthquakes Damage Buildings, Cause Landslides in Costa Rica
DOC.TEXT: Two strong earthquakes rocked Costa Rica Sunday, damaging buildings, causing landslides and sending panic-stricken people into the streets. No injuries were reported. The quakes, measuring 5.5 and 6.9 on the Richter scale, struck at 7:16 a.m. (8:16 a.m. EST) and 7:23 a.m., according to Waverly Person, an official at the U.S. Geological Survey in Golden, Colo. The epicenter of the quakes was located in the Pacific Ocean, 80 miles southwest of San Jose, he said. Federico Guendel of the Vulcanological and Seismological Observatory in San Jose said 60 aftershocks struck in the hour after the second quake. People in San Jose and other cities rushed out of homes and buildings as the structures rocked violently. Many terrified people huddled in the capital's streets and parks, waiting for the earth to stop trembling. Plaster, cornices and other adornments on older buildings crashed into the streets of San Jose. Many windowpanes and shop windows also shattered. A water boiler exploded at the Hotel Balmoral during the earthquakes and several of the building's walls cracked. Walls also cracked at the La Merced Roman Catholic Church, one of the capital's oldest buildings. In Alajuela, a city 12 miles north of San Jose, the cupola of the local cathedral cracked in half during the second quake, and long fissures appeared in the sides of many buildings. The main highway linking San Jose with the Atlantic Coast was blocked by several landslides and police ordered traffic halted until further notice. A Red Cross news release reported ``considerable'' damage to buildings in the Pacific Coast port of Puntarenas. Heavy structural damage also was reported in the nearby village of Cobano. No details were immediately available. A spokesman for the Red Cross, Carlos Gutierrez, said a nationwide check by his organization, police and the fire department turned up no casualties. The quakes were the strongest in the nation since 1983, when a pair of temblors measuring 6.2 and 7.3 on the Richter scale rattled southern Costa Rica, causing widespread panic but no casualties. Another quake of 4.7 rocked San Jose in February 1989. The Richter scale is a gauge of the energy released by an earthquake, as measured by the ground motion recorded on a seismograph. A quake of magnitude 5 can cause considerable damage, while one measuring 6 can cause severe damage. Every increase of one number of the Richter scale means that the ground motion is 10 times greater.

DOC.HEAD: Trails Center Opens in Independence
DOC.TEXT: Two 10-year-old cousins whose ancestors journeyed west more than a century ago cut a ceremonial ribbon to open a museum dedicated to the trails pioneers traveled. The National Frontier Trails Center commemorates the role that Independence, established in 1827, played in outfitting travelers who headed west on the Santa Fe, Oregon and California trails. About 200 people watched as Jennifer Zimmerman of Lee's Summit and Jacob Queener of Independence cut a ribbon Saturday afternoon. Jennifer and Jacob's ancestors traveled to California in 1856 and 1865. Outside the museum, a handful of living-history enthusiasts in 19th century garb milled around a campsite erected for the weekend. Inside, visitors examined exhibits telling the trails' story through diary excerpts, journals and letters. Construction of the museum was financed with $2.4 million from the state. The city of Independence picked up other costs, bringing the total to $3 million.

DOC.HEAD: Moslem Militants Hang Abducted Legislator, Politician
DOC.TEXT: Moslem separatists in Kashmir hanged a politician and a former legislator, police said Sunday. The separatists accused the former legislator of being a police informer and following ``un-Islamic practices,'' including womanizing and drinking liquor. The body of Ghulam Nabi, a member of the Congress Party of former Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi, was found Sunday on a road in Kullar, 40 miles north of Srinagar, said police officials who cannot be identified under briefing rules. No group claimed responsibility for the killing, but the police blamed Moslem guerrillas fighting for indepdendence of the predominantly Moslem Jammu-Kashmir state from Hindu India. Police said Nabi was hanged, a method often used by the Moslem militants to kill their victims. The body of former Kashmir state legislator Mir Mustafa was found by residents Sunday on a road along a rivulet in Srinagar's Batmaloo area, police said. Mustafa was kidnapped by unidentified gunmen who pulled him out of his car Saturday near his home in Badgam, 12 miles west of Srinagar. At least 197 people, mostly Moslem demonstrators, have been killed in Kashmir since Jan. 20 when the government launched a crackdown on separatists. The Hezbul Mujahedeen, or the party of the Islamic holy warriors, is fighting for independence of the predominantly Moslem Jammu-Kashmir state from Hindu India. A man claiming to be the group's spokesman called The Associated Press office in Srinagar on Sunday and said Mustafa was killed because ``he was found indulging in un-Islamic acts and was informing the Indian Intelligence Bureau on our activities.'' The man refused to be identified. Sixty-four percent of Jammu-Kashmir's 6 million people are Moslem, but nationwide Moslems make up only 12 percent of India's 880 million people, who are mainly Hindu.

DOC.HEAD: Dead Sea Scrolls to be Carbon-dated to Settle Controversy
DOC.TEXT: The Dead Sea Scrolls, which include some of the earliest known Biblical texts, will be subjected to carbon-14 dating to discover whether they were written by a Jewish group or early Christians, officials said Sunday. Magen Broshi, custodian of the Israel Museum's Shrine of the Book, where some of the scrolls are on public display, said at least 12 of the 799 scrolls will be dated using new carbon-14 techniques. The dating would help settle arguments and conflicting theories about whether the scrolls were the product of a Jewish group known as the Essenes or a much later group of early Christians, said Orna Hess, a spokeswoman for the Antiquities Authority. Most biblical scholars believe the scrolls date to the second century B.C. or late third century B.C. based on paleography, or analysis of handwriting styles, Broshi said. ``We relied on paleography. We will now see if this method agrees with physics,'' Broshi said. ``I don't believe there is any urgent need but this will keep people happy.'' Broshi said the testing would quiet critics like Robert Eisenman, head of religious studies at California State University at Long Beach, who do not accept the non-scientific dating. In a telephone interview, Eisenman demanded that objective observers be allowed to witness the dating process and that more than one laboratory carry out the tests. He said this was necessary because the scrolls are controlled by a team of scholars who have a vested interest in preserving their theories, which are based on the established chronology. ``In order to have a fair process, one that would not be open to future questions, people of differing shades of opinion should be brought into the process as observers,'' Eisenman said. Eisenman has backed the controversial theory that the unpublished scrolls may be the work of early Christians. His argument is based on the wording of the texts, such as the use of certain phrases known to have been common among early Christians and indirect references to the rule of King Herod the Great. Traditionally, the scrolls are viewed as the work of a small mysterious sect known as the Essenes. Scholars of this traditional school say they provide an insight into the life and religious thought of the ancient sect of Jews as well as the roots of Christianity. Ms. Hess said a small fragment had already been dated at Israel's Weizmann Institute of Science. She declined to discuss the results or give details as to how large a fragment was tested. Broshi said negotiations were under way with a European university with more advanced techniques to do the main body of work, which was expected to start within the next few weeks. Neither Broshi nor Hess would say which university was involved. None of the papyrus scrolls have been previously carbon dated, because until a few years ago too much material had to be destroyed in the process, Broshi said. The linen wrapping in which some scrolls were found was dated more than 30 years ago, using primitive techniques. It dated the cloth to 33 A.D., plus or minus 200 years. Scientists can date organic material on the basis of the amount of radioactive carbon-14 remaining. The new carbon-14 technique, called Accelerator Mass Spectrometry, requires only a small about of parchment for testing. It was first employed to date a 27,000-year-old wooly mammouth found in Siberia in 1977. The first scrolls were found in caves at Qumran, overlooking the Dead Sea, in 1947, and others were excavated over a 10-year span from 11 caves. Some scrolls represent the earliest existing copies of books of the Bible. Others contain poetry, stories and legal texts.

DOC.HEAD: Bright & Brief
DOC.TEXT: In the end, all Karen and Robert Elliott could agree on was that they cared about their two cats. They cared so much, in fact, that they made the pets part of their divorce settlement. Davidson County Probate Judge Jim Everett granted the divorce last week on the grounds of irreconcilable differences. The agreement includes cat custody and visitation rights. The Elliotts had no property to divide, according to court documents that awarded Robert Elliott custody of the ``two feline pets ... of great sentimental value.'' Karen Elliott was granted ``reasonable'' visitation rights _ as long as she calls first.

Linda Spanky Gray gave a lively rendition of a Dizzy Gillespie's jazz tune, Salt Peanuts, to win first place in the 24th annual Conch Shell Blowing Contest. Gray, 37, who is trained in trumpet, slide trombone and French horn, earned top adult honors in Saturday's contest, which is part of a three-month celebration honoring the heritage of the southernmost city in the continental United States. The origin of the event dates back several hundred years to when Calusa Indians and pirates lived in the Keys and used the conch for communicating. A toot was a signal of survival or distress. A total of 38 contestants teased tunes from the tightly coiled mollusk, including selections such as ``Sentimental Journey,'' ``Yellowbird'' and Ludwig van Beethoven's ``Ode to Joy.''

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Supplies to Angolan Rebels Stepped Up
DOC.TEXT: The United States has stepped up support for anti-Marxist Angolan rebels and has shipped specially equipped four-wheel-drive vehicles that could give them an edge, a U.S. diplomatic source said. The rebels in recent months have been facing one of the biggest offensives in the 15-year-old civil war from the government backed by Cuba and the Soviet Union. ``Three Toyota Landcruisers are being stripped daily here and outfitted with heavy machine guns. They (the rebels) are going to use them for hit-and-run attacks,'' said the source, who spoke on condition of anonymity. The vehicles are considered ideal for traveling on the sand and scrub-covered roads in southeastern Angola, the site of most of the fighting in the war. The source said at least 120,000 gallons of diesel fuel were also being shipped from Kinshasa to Jonas Savimbi's UNITA (National Union for the Total Independence of Angola) rebels. The United States has pledged to support Savimbi until Angolan President Jose Eduardo dos Santos agrees to ``national reconciliation,'' short-hand for accepting negotations that will lead to power-sharing with UNITA. During last week's tour of southern Africa by Secretary of State James A. Baker III, a senior official traveling with the secretary reaffirmed his government would not permit the Angolan government to crush Savimbi's rebels. The United States provides about $50 million annually in aid to the rebels and stepped up assistance after South Africa agreed to cease UNITA support as part of a regional peace plan. In Washington, White House spokesman Bill Harlow said he was unaware of any stepped up aid shipments to the Angolan rebels. During Baker's visit to Kinshasa on Saturday, one of at least two American C-141 transport planes believed used to resupply UNITA had disappeared from sight. Both were on the tarmac Sunday morning. A week earlier, a reporter passing through the airport counted four of the camouflaged planes bearing the U.S. flag. Baker last week held talks with the Angolan president and Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze while in Windhoek, Namibia, for independence celebrations. Baker met Savimbi on Friday night and Zaire President Mobutu Sese Seko on Saturday. Mobutu has been serving as a mediator for the warring parties in Angola. He brokered a cease-fire last June, but it quickly fell apart. He continues to allow the United States to supply the UNITA rebels through Zaire. Officials traveling with Baker said no major progress had been made because the Angolan president continued to insist on terms that amounted to a surrender by Savimbi, whose forces had not been defeated on the battlefield. Baker has sought to enlist Soviet support in efforts to negotiate an end to the Angolan fighting, and Shevardnadze has indicated his government is ready to cooperate in peace efforts. Savimbi says the Soviets have been pouring weapons into Angola _ more than $1 billion worth in the last two years _ in a bid to shore up the Angolan government forces before all Cuban forces have withdrawn. Under a Soviet- and U.S.-brokered agreement between South Africa, Angola and Cuba, the 50,000 Cuban troops in Angola are to be pulled out by mid-1991. South Africa granted Namibia independence March 21 as part of the arrangement and has withdrawn support for UNITA. Angolan government forces have pushed farther into rebel territory during an unprecedented rainy-season offensive than ever before in the war. For the past several weeks there has been heavy fighting near the strategic southeastern town of Mavinga. Four-wheel drive vehicles could give UNITA an edge once the rain stops in the next month or so.

DOC.HEAD: Like Snail Darter, Red Squirrel Caught in Environmental Limelight
DOC.TEXT: They're few in number, and their sky-island habitat has long lain undisturbed. But 180 tiny Mount Graham red squirrels could prove a big obstacle to construction of the world's most powerful optical telescope. The University of Arizona wants nothing more than to coexist with the mountaintop rodents, an endangered subspecies. But the builder of a $200 million observatory atop 10,709-foot Mount Graham is having to tread carefully. The 8-ounce squirrel, or Tamiasciurus hudsonicus grahamensis, has touched off a two-year ecological controversy that has split the scientific community, pitted one federal agency against another, and drawn environmentalists into a battle against telescope proponents from as far away as the Vatican. U.S. District Judge Alfredo C. Marquez will hear closing arguments Monday afternoon on whether a third federal biological study is needed before construction begins this year on two smaller telescopes. If all goes smoothly, the Columbus Project, a 600-inch-diameter device expected to be six times more powerful than any telescope in use, will be built in the mid-1990s on the 8.6-acre tract in the Pinaleno Mountains 110 miles northeast of Tucson. Just 180 of the squirrels, which have been traced back 10,000 years or more, are believed to remain, and Mount Graham is their only known habitat. Opposition groups say perching the telescopes on Emerald Peak, one of Mount Graham's three peaks, can only assure that the squirrels become a biological footnote. ``It's biologically indefensible to develop on that mountain,'' said Dr. Robin Silver, spokesman for the Maricopa Audubon Society. ``We will win this case. The question is will we win it before the university wreaks too much destruction on the mountain?'' The university, argued its vice president for research, Michael Cusanovich, ``is the most likely participant to provide the basis for the Mount Graham red squirrel's recovery.'' It spent more than $200,000 last year on research and monitoring and will put aside more than $100,000 annually for several years, he said. A two-mile access road for the Mount Graham International Observatory has already been built. But opponents have so far held up construction of the observatory buildings. The squirrels apparently have some militant supporters. One mailed an anonymous death threat to telescope proponent Conrad Istock, head of the University of Arizona's ecology and evolutionary biology department. Eleven of the department's 28 faculty members and 41 of 58 graduate students have voiced opposition to the observatory. But students at the 38,000-student university later voted down by 57 percent to 43 percent a nonbinding initiative opposing the observatory. Fewer than 5,000 students voted. In July 1988, the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service concluded in a biological report for the U.S. Forest Service, the site's landlord, that the telescopes could coexist with the squirrel. Arizona's congressional delegation then pushed through legislation ordering the Forest Service to grant the university a special-use permit allowing construction. But an environmental coalition intervened with a lawsuit. Naturalists have staged demonstrations outside the Vatican Embassy and the Smithsonian Institution in Washington. The university says it will advertise soon for construction bids for the two smaller telescopes, one of which is partly financed by the Vatican Observatory. Pope John Paul II is among the Vatican's astronomy buffs. Two biologists who took part in the Fish and Wildlife Service study alleged in depositions that officials at the agency ordered researchers to argue in favor of construction. The agency's regional director, Mike Spear, upheld the study as ``biologically sound.'' But, last month, after the construction site was designated as a critical habitat, Spear called for a review study. However, the Forest Service says the congressional act authorizes the first three telescopes and exempts them from further review. Spear said the Endangered Species Act makes clear there should be reconsultation before change in the habitat, while Forest Service regional chief Dave Jolly said Congress intentionally skirted the Act. University officials contend that poor cone crops in recent years have hurt the squirrel population, that hunting, logging, use of off-road vehicles and Christmas tree-cutting have been stopped because of the planned observatory, and that 60 to 80 acres will be reforested. Silver, who is a wildlife photographer, likened the squirrel's predicament to that of the snail darter, a 3-inch fish that delayed the Tennessee River dam project for six years during the 1970s before it was transplanted to the Hiwassee River. ``They're very similar in that the developmental groups managed to ignore ecosystem destruction and focused the issue on one creature that was easily demeaned in their project,'' Silver said. The dam was completed with Congress first amending the Endangered Species Act in 1978 to allow an exemption from the law, then exempting the dam from any law that would hinder its construction, he said. Dan Campbell, director of the Nature Conservancy in Arizona, says Mount Graham has Arizona's greatest density of black bears, and is the farthest south that elk can be found in the United States. ``It's the general habitat which we really need to protect and conserve in order to protect the species,'' he said. ``It's like a lifeboat. If you keep the lifeboat from sinking, then the species stay there.''

DOC.HEAD: Israel Enthralled by Scandal of Army Captain and Palestinian Girl
DOC.TEXT: Television viewers got the latest Sunday about the affair that is scandalizing Israel _ the case of the Israeli army captain suspended from his job over alleged trysting with a Palestinian woman. The wronged wife in what's being called the ``Love and the Intefadeh'' affair appeared as a blacked-out figure on the evening TV news to support her husband's story that he was really trying to recruit the dark-haired Arab woman as an informer. The story of Capt. Avi Marak and 20-year-old Abir Mattar has hit newspaper front pages this weekend largely because with the wall of hatred that has grown between Jews and Arabs in the Intefadeh _ or uprising _ such a romance seems unthinkable. A military source Sunday confirmed that Marak, who was a company commander for Israel's military government in the occupied West Bank, is being investigated on suspicion of ``inappropriate behavior.'' According to Israeli newspapers, Marak held nightly secret rendezvous with the young woman from the Christian village of Beit Jallah near Bethlehem for between four and eight months. They usually spent their time together in military jeeps or pickup trucks, the reports said. The trysts ended after Marak's wife, Ricky, found out, the Maariv daily said. Early one morning, Mrs. Marak went to the home of the Palestinian woman, who also is married, and the two got into a scuffle, according to news reports. The captain then hauled his wife off in a jeep, the reports said. But the shadowy figure on the evening news backed her husband's story that he was recruiting an informer to act against Palestinians involved in the 27-month-old uprising against Israeli occupation of the West Bank and Gaza Strip. After saying some unpleasant things about Mrs. Mattar's reputation, Mrs. Marak added: ``This is a relation based on (military) security.'' She said her husband ``never told me anything because he doesn't let me in on military affairs.'' Marak, who is still being questioned after removal from his post earlier this month, told Maariv that he had been seeking an informer. Other newspapers noted Mrs. Mattar's family had a reputation of assisting Israeli authorities. Mrs. Mattar was quoted as saying she wants to divorce her husband, who is in jail for attempted murder, and marry Marak. ``We are happy together,'' she told the Yediot Ahronot daily. ``When Avi divorces his wife, I will also get a divorce and convert to marry him.'' Mrs. Marak told newspapers she hopes to keep her marriage intact. On television, she said she saw her husband's story as material for a television script she has been writing as a hobby. ``I am putting this all in the script,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Airline Office Burned During Anti-Hungarian Protests
DOC.TEXT: An office of the Hungarian state airline was set on fire Sunday in Romania's capital, and protesters rallied nationwide in anger over purported secessionist plans by ethnic Hungarians in Transylvania. No injuries were reported in the fire, and damage was minor. A police officer blamed hooligans, but anti-Hungarian slogans had been painted on the Malev airline office's facade in the last week as ethnic tension mounted. Several hours later, Hungary demanded Romania take steps against ``terrorist acts'' and protect Hungarian citizens and offices in this country, Hungary's MTI news agency said. Despite Romanian government appeals for calm, anti-Hungarian sentiments burst into the open Sunday at rallies by several hundred people in Bucharest, the Romanian capital. Smaller protests were reported in other Romania towns. Romanians fear that a campaign by Transylvania's 2 million ethnic Hungarians for education in their own language is a veiled push for autonomy or even union with Hungary, which ruled the disputed region for centuries. Transylvania was given to Romania in 1920 in the aftermath of World War I; it was briefly ceded again to Hungary during World War II. The post-revolutionary government has ruled out any possibility of secession for the region. Authorities at the scene of Sunday's fire at the airline office provided few details. A paramilitary police officer standing guard over burned debris outside told reporters that unidentified hooligans set fire to the office about 3 a.m. The officer declined to give his name. In the Transylvanian town of Tirgu Mures, where at least seven people were killed last week and about 300 injured in ethnic strife, Romanian churchgoers prayed for peace outside the city's Orthodox cathedral Sunday. In Bucharest, about 700 people chanting ``Tirgu Mures is Romania'' and ``Barbarians behind bars'' circled the headquarters of the interim Romanian government on Victory Square. Troops and paramilitary police armed with automatic rifles and batons guarded the government building. Critics say the government, which took control after the December revolution ousted Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu, has not done enough to control the ethnic unrest. With the end of Ceausescu's hard-line regime, both Romanians and ethnic Hungarians have more freedom to express themselves, and the new atmosphere has led to clashes. ``Ceausescu hated us, but at least we were not afraid to walk in the streets,'' said a Hungarian writer in Tirgu Mures, declining to give his name.

DOC.HEAD: Nasser's Widow Dies
DOC.TEXT: Taheya Kazem, widow of the late President Gamal Abdel Nasser, died Sunday, the state-owned Middle East News Agency and Cairo television announced. She was 66. The announcement said she will be burried Monday after a funeral but gave no further details. President Hosni Mubarak and other high-ranking Egyptian officials were expected to attend the funeral. Nasser, who took power in a military coup and ruled Egypt for 18 years, died on Sept. 28, 1970, of a heart attack. Unlike his successor, Anwar Sadat, Nasser did not allow his wife to take part in public social activities. Jihan Sadat's activities were prominently published in Egyptian news media at the time of her husband's rule. Sadat was assassinated on Oct. 6, 1981, by Moslem extremists.

DOC.HEAD: Clouds and Drizzle Linger Over Mid-Atlantic Coast
DOC.TEXT: Clouds and drizzle lingered along the middle Atlantic Coast on Sunday after dumping a record amount of snow. Much of north-central Texas also was wet. The storm that created heavy snow from the lower Missouri Valley to the middle Atlantic Coast broke snowfall records Saturday in Philadelphia, with 2.2 inches, and at the Atlantic City International Airport near Pomona, N.J., with 2.4 inches. A day earlier, temperatures in those two areas were in the upper 60s. Clouds and light rain remained along the mid-Atlantic Coast early Sunday afternoon. Light rain and drizzle extended from the southern High Plains to Arkansas. Freezing drizzle fell on parts of northern Texas in the morning but changed to light rain as temperatures rose during the day. Heavy showers fell on parts of north central Texas. The rest of the nation enjoyed dry weather. Skies were sunny in the West, and from Montana and Wyoming to the Ohio Valley and the Great Lakes region. Temperatures were only in the 30s in Oklahoma and northern Texas, as well as the northern and central Plains and the northeastern United States early in the afternoon. But temperatures rose into the 70s and 80s in Southeast and the valleys and deserts of the Southwest. Morning lows were mostly in the teens and 20s from the Rocky Mountains to New England, with readings in the single digits or below zero in the northern Rockies and the northern High Plains. The low of 13 degrees at International Airport in Kansas City, Mo., was the lowest for the date in 18 years of record-keeping there. The low for the Lower 48 states was 5 degrees below zero at West Yellowstone, Mont.

DOC.HEAD: Investigators Search for Arsonist who Sets Trees Ablaze
DOC.TEXT: More than 100 of this area's trademark palm trees have caught fire over the last five months, and investigators suspect an arsonist, possibly working with a driver, is to blame, officials said. Some of the fires have spread to nearby houses or cars, doing minor damage, said Fire Battalion Chief William Burmester. Burmester said he was worried the consequences of future blazes could be more serious. ``There is always a danger, even with a guy like this who is not setting large fires,'' he said. Most of the 104 fires since October have occurred in early evening in the adjoining suburbs of Reseda, Canoga Park and Northridge about 20 miles north of downtown Los Angeles. On several occasions, trash rather than trees was set on fire. The outbreak represents the largest number of apparently related arsons in memory, arson investigators said. No motive has emerged. On Jan. 23, a 16-year-old Reseda boy with emotional problems was arrested after admitting he set fire to palm trees and trash in copycat arsons. Arson investigator Glen Lucero said there may be other copycats at work, but suspected that most of the fires were set by one person or perhaps two people working together. ``The fires are set so quickly,'' Lucero said. ``It could be one guy lighting them and somebody else doing the driving.'' ``It is almost completely random as far as the locations go,'' said fellow investigator Bill Cass. ``Recently, he's been more interested in trees than trash. We don't know what that means.''

DOC.HEAD: Mandela Calls For Students To End Boycotts
DOC.TEXT: Nelson Mandela on Sunday urged black students to return to class and call off anti-apartheid boycotts that have disrupted schools for the past several years. ``Without education, you can forget about liberation,'' Mandela told an estimated 30,000 blacks in the northern town of Pietersburg. The statement appeared directed at young, militant blacks who have led the school boycotts under the slogan, ``Liberation before education.'' ``The tactic of the boycott cannot hope to win our battles in the educational arena,'' said Mandela, who is deputy president of the African National Congress, the nation's leading anti-apartheid group. ``Our stayaways and boycotts are giving the education departments one long holiday.'' Since the mid-1980s, black students have staged frequent and prolonged boycotts to protest the inferior education system for blacks and to press other grievances. In some parts of the country, blacks students have attended classes only a few days this year. Black teachers also have been on strike in some areas. The boycotts have coincided with declining test scores by black students. Last year, only 42 percent of blacks passed their matriculation examination following their final year of high school. It was the poorest showing in years. Mandela, a lawyer, has repeatedly stressed the importance of education in recent speeches. He also has criticized the conditions of black schools, most of which are understaffed and lack proper materials. On Sunday, Mandela also called on blacks to unite, saying factional violence was diverting attention from the struggle against apartheid, South Africa's system of racial segregation. ``Apartheid has deeply wounded our society, making us enemies of each other,'' he said. More than 300 blacks have been killed, mostly in factional violence, since Mandela was released from prison Feb. 11 after serving 27 years for launching the ANC's sabotage campaign. President F.W. de Klerk legalized the ANC and other anti-apartheid groups last month as part of his white government's program to create a political role for the country's black majority. Elsewhere Sunday, the Zulu homeland's leader, Mangosuthu Buthelezi, said he planned to meet soon with Mandela, an old friend and now a political rival. Supporters of Mandela's ANC and Buthelezi's Inkatha movement have been battling since 1986 for political supremacy in the southeastern province of Natal, leaving more than 3,000 blacks dead. ``It is violence against democracy and against the black struggle for liberation,'' Buthelezi told several thousand people at a stadium in the port city of Durban. Buthelezi gave no date for the meeting with Mandela, but he said it could be as soon as this week.

DOC.HEAD: Afghan Rebel Commander Killed in Ambush
DOC.TEXT: A key Afghan rebel commander, who was also known as leader of a drug empire in southern Afghanistan, was killed Sunday in an ambush outside this border city, Western diplomats said. Nazim Akhundzada and his six heavily armed bodyguards were gunned down outside a guerrilla compound 10 miles east of Peshawar, diplomats said on condition of anonymity. No one claimed responsibility for the killings, and the diplomats said they had few details. Akhundzada's drug operation took in most of Afghanistan's southern province of Helmand, Afghan and diplomatic sources said.
