Afghanistan's Marxist government regularly accuses the rebels of financing their insurgency with large-scale poppy production. The guerrillas and Pakistan have made similar charges against the Soviet-backed Kabul government. Late last year, Akhundzada reportedly asked the United States for $2 million a month to stop growing poppies, which can be used to make opium and heroin. U.S. Embassy officials in Islamabad denied he was given any money. ``It just wasn't true,'' said a U.S. diplomat who spoke on condition of anonymity. ``He was told that because he was growing poppies, we couldn't deal with him at all.'' Afghan rebels have been fighting for almost 12 years to oust successive Communist governments in Kabul, Afghanistan's capital. The insurgents are supported by the United States, Pakistan and several Arab states, including Saudi Arabia. The protracted war has been blamed for increased poppy production, particularly in the lawless border frontier between Pakistan and Afghanistan. Afghan and Western sources said Akhundzada had many enemies. ``It got to be a long list very quickly,'' one diplomat said. The commander had a long-standing feud with a rival rebel group, Hezb-i-Islami, led by the firebrand fundamentalist Gulbuddin Hekmatyar. ``He threw almost all Hezb people out of Helmand province,'' said one Afghan guerrilla leader, who also spoke on condition of anonymity. Akhundzada belonged to Harakat-i-Inqilab-i-Islami, or the Islamic Revolutionary Movement. It is one of the seven major rebel groups with headquarters in Peshawar. ``He was one of Harakat's strongest and most powerful commanders,'' said Hamid Karzai, a rebel spokesman. Last year, Akhundzada waged a bloody drug war in Helmand province against a rival commander of Rasul Sayyaf's fundamentalist Ittihad-i-Islami, or Islamic Unity guerrilla party. Akhundzada's death came five days after one of Sayyaf's field commanders, Painda Mohammad, was killed outside Peshawar, said Qaribur Saeed, a spokesman for Hekmatyar's party.

DOC.HEAD: Modigliani Painting Biggest Prize at Record-breaking Auction
DOC.TEXT: A 1918 oil painting by Amedeo Modigliani was sold Sunday for $11.5 million during a record-breaking auction of 20th century art. The Drouot auction house said total sales were $107 million, a record for Paris. The Modigliani painting, ``The Beautiful Shopkeeper,'' claimed the biggest price, and marked a record sale in France for the Italian artist. The identity of the buyer was not disclosed. ``The Fishermen of Nanterre,'' completed in 1906 by Maurice de Vlaminck, went for $10.5 million, the second-largest price. A 1953 Picasso, ``Woman and Dog Playing, Blue Background,'' was sold for $4.4 million. Potential buyers in Tokyo were able to participate in the auction via due to a live television transmission by satellite. Of the more than 80 works on sale, 53 were from the private collection of a Parisian woman identified by the auction house only as Mrs. Bourdon. These included two Modiglianis, three Picassos, the Vlaminck, and works by Henri Matisse, Raoul Dufy, Man Ray and others.

DOC.HEAD: Precede MOSCOW
Soviet Soldiers Seize Lithuanian Schools, But Talks Under Way
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 27 grafs to UPDATE with Soviet-Lithuanian talks, details; pickup graf 23 pvs, `At least...' TRIMS thereafter. No pickup. CHANGES byline.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto VIL2
DOC.TEXT: Soviet military commanders Sunday sent soldiers with automatic weapons to occupy two Communist Party schools in Lithuania but later agreed to discuss building security with the breakaway republic. It was the latest escalation in the war of nerves between the Kremlin and the leadership of this Baltic republic, which declared itself independent March 11. The commander of all Soviet ground forces, Gen. Valentin I. Varennikov, accused independence leaders of plotting to arrest Communists and send them to prison. Lithuanian President Vytautas Landsbergis said he talked twice on the telephone with Varennikov, whose presence in Vilnius was a sign of Moscow's concern with the situation in the small Baltic republic. The general reportedly said no more buildings would be taken overnight but made no promises beyond that. The soldiers occupied Lithuania's Institute of Marxism-Leninism and the Higher Party School. The republic's deputy premier, Romualdas Ozolas, said earlier he feared Soviet forces might storm Lithuania's legislative headquarters. Landsbergis asked for a meeting to receive an explanation about the building seizures, and Varennikov sent four officers to the Lithuanian parliament building. In a brief news conference afterward, Landsbergis quoted the officers as telling him the buildings had been seized at the request of Communist Party members who remain loyal to Moscow. ``We expressed surprise and astonishment that the military can occupy buildings at the request of a political organization, and we asked if such requests come from other organizations whether they will fulfill them,'' Landsbergis said. ``We did not receive a concrete answer.'' Although Varennikov made no promises not to seize more buildings Monday, Landsbergis said the two sides agreed to form a joint committee on control of such buildings. More meetings on the issue were set for Monday morning, he said. Franciskas Benucius, a director of the Higher Party School, said 30 soldiers who arrived there told him they were sent to guard the building. ``I asked, `What are you protecting it from?' and they didn't know,'' he said. The school is used by both the Lithuanian Communist Party that has broken with Moscow and the smaller group that remains loyal. Officials expected the school to open Monday despite the soldiers' presence. Despite the increasing tension, there was no sign Sunday that the Soviet army was trying to round up hundreds of Lithuanians who deserted. A deadline of Saturday had been set for their return. For days, as President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and other Moscow officials have squeezed the defiant Baltic state, official media reports have criticized a draft bill in Lithuania's new parliament that they say could mean imprisonment for those who speak out against independence. Varennikov said workers he met with at a Vilnius electronics factory were ``convinced that Sajudis is trying to create in the republic a real dictatorship.'' Sajudis is the grass-roots political movement that has pressed for Lithuanian independence from the Soviet Union. Its candidates won an absolute majority in the parliament that declared independence, and election commission officials said Sunday it also won a sizeable majority in voting Saturday for the Vilnius city council. But Varennikov charged Sajudis, headed by Landsbergis, is conducting an ``open psychological war against dissidents.'' ``In conditions of this `democracy,' many people are frightened,'' he said in an interview printed Sunday by the newspaper Sovietskaya Rossiya, the official newspaper of Lithuania's giant neighbor, the Russian republic. ``And when a law is adopted prohibiting criticism of the government, you can expect arrests,'' Varennikov said. Asked by the paper whether he meant Communists who remained loyal to Moscow could be arrested, he replied: ``All Communists, I think. They already have divided the party, now it remains to send Communists to prison camps or jails.'' The Lithuanian government has vowed to establish a fully democratic multiparty political system that respects all internationally recognized human rights. But it says that as Lithuania establishes its own law, residents of the republic will be expected to obey it rather than Soviet law. Lithuanian leaders accuse Gorbachev of conducting his own psychological war against them through the media and with a series of demands and military maneuvers, including a convoy of about 100 army vehicles that roared through downtown Vilnius early Saturday. Gorbachev and his advisers have pledged not to use force. But the Soviet leader has ordered Lithuanians to surrender all firearms and told them not to sign up for volunteer units under the republic's government. At least 28 Lithuanian deserters were in a refuge organized by the Lithuanian government at the New Vilnius Psychiatric Hospital dormitory as Sunday dawned. ``We expect that nobody would dare to attack the Red Cross,'' said one of them, 20-year-old Darius Baceulis. And if troops do come after them, 19-year-old Arunas Vazinskas said, life would still ``be better in prison than in the army.'' Many Baltic draftees have complained of brutality and harassment by fellow soldiers and officers, especially since their republics strengthened their drive for independence. Landsbergis on Saturday suggested that the soldiers seek protection in churches, a traditional haven for people seeking to avoid arrest. But no soldiers appeared to have taken his advice. Many preferred to stay with friends. A Roman Catholic priest preaching at the main cathedral in Vilnius on Sunday urged believers to remain calm. ``Our big enemy would like to make us lose our patience in order to use force,'' he said. ``I beg you to be calm. Be patient.''

DOC.BYLINE: Immune System May Battle Melanoma, Studies Suggest ^By MALCOLM RITTER
DOC.TEXT: Two strategies that boost the immune system to battle the most dangerous form of skin cancer show promise in early tests with patients, a researcher said Sunday. Twenty-three percent of patients showed evidence of some remission of melanoma after injections in one of the experimental treatments primed their bodies to attack certain proteins found on melanoma cells, said Malcolm Mitchell. The injections are called theraccines, short for therapeutic vaccines, because they seek to treat cancer rather than prevent disease, he said. Mitchell, a professor of medicine and microbiology at the University of Southern California School of Medicine in Los Angeles, described the work at a science writers seminar sponsored by the American Cancer Society. About 27,600 new cases of melanoma are expected this year, with 6,300 deaths, the society says. Intense exposure to the sun is a chief cause. Mitchell's experimental injections make the immune system seek out proteins called antigens on cancerous cells. The preparations are made from melanoma cells grown in the laboratory. Injections were done under the skin once a week for four weeks with a final injection on week six. Patients who responded were treated with a single monthly booster and semiannual courses of five more doses. In 79 melanoma patients, the treatment produced a complete remission in 5 percent and a partial remission in 18 percent, Mitchell said. Another 10 percent showed minor responses, defined as tumor shrinkage of 26 percent to 50 percent. No major side effects were observed, he said. Other researchers have reported similar work. ``Clearly this is an attraactive approach,'' said John Laszlo, the cancer society's senior vice president for research. Mitchell also reported on results from treating melanoma patients with low doses of interleukin-2, a natural substance used by the immune system, and a standard cancer drug called cyclophosphamide. Both drugs were given at about one-third the dose used in experiments or therapy. In 39 patients, the combination produced a 28 percent response rate, including two complete remissions and eight partial remissions, Mitchell said. Potentially, this treatment could be done by any hospital, and its results are comparable to a more complex treatment in which interleukin-2 is combined outside the body with white blood cells and then reinjected into the patient, Mitchell said. In what he called the ``down note'' of his talk, Mitchell said some other forms of therapy will have to be found to deal with the spread of melanoma cells to the brain, where they can form new cancers. In a separate presentation, a researcher said a study of 200 people with or without melanoma suggests that six factors define people at high risk for getting the disease. They are blond or red hair, marked freckling of the upper back, the presence of rough, red bumps called actinic keratoses caused by to sun exposure, a history of melanoma in other family members, having had three or more blistering sunburns during one's teen-age years, and having spent three or more years at an outdoor summer job as a teen-ager. Having any one or two of these factors gives a person a three to four times increased chance of developing melanoma, said Darrell Rigel of the New York University School of Medicine. People with three or more of the factors run an increased risk of 20 to 25 times, he said. People at high risk should be taught the ways to detect melanoma early, when it is at a highly curable stage, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Illegal Clubs Proliferate Despite Efforts to Close Them
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 11 grafs to UPDATE with mayor promising to close unlicensed clubs, figures on number of clubs, number of people killed in city's worst fire. Pick up 10th graf pvs, `Just about...' DELETES next-to-last graf to conform.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Social Club Fire, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of dangerous and illegal social clubs thrive in New York despite efforts to close them, because people in poor neighborhoods have few alternatives for entertainment, officials say. ``People are literally taking their lives in their hands at these clubs,'' Bronx Borough President Fernando Ferrer said after a fire Sunday killed 87 people at the Happy Land social club. It was the city's deadliest blaze since 145 people were killed in a fire at a garment factory, the Triangle Shirtwaist Co. of Manhattan, 79 years ago to the day. Authorities said most of the predawn revelers were trapped on a second-story dance floor and died from smoke inhalation. The building lacked proper exits and other safeguards. The 4-year-old club, which didn't have a liquor or cabaret license, was shut down for the second time Nov. 1, 1989, by the city Buildings Department, but reopened illegally, Mayor David Dinkins said. Despite periodic campaigns to close them, social clubs have been centers of urban problems ranging from noise and double-parking to gambling, drug dealing and prostitution. Mayor David Dinkins estimated there are at least 700 social clubs in the city. They often are rife with building, health and fire code violations that can lead to tragedy. Six people died in a 1988 fire at a Bronx club, five in a Brooklyn club fire in 1985, and 25 people were killed in another Bronx fire in 1976. ``I don't know what it's going to take _ an army _ to stop them from going to places like this,'' said newly elected U.S. Rep. Jose Serrano after visiting the scene Sunday. City records reviewed Sunday showed 173 social clubs had been given orders to vacate, Dinkins said at an afternoon news conference. ``Tonight, we will commence to check those places, see that they're in fact closed,'' he said. ``We'll see to it that they certainly aren't open come the next weekend.'' Just about anyone can go to a social club, despite the term's implication of exclusivity. An employee usually keeps an eye on the door, but a club member is generally anyone who walks in on a given night. ``They range from a group of elderly men who get together to play cards and watch a ballgame on a Sunday afternoon to full-fledged nightclub operations,'' said Richard Chernela, a state Liquor Authority spokesman. New York State liquor licenses cost up to $5,100 and are good for three years. But many club operators don't apply for one, sometimes because they or potential employees may have criminal records that would disqualify them. While the city's licensed bars are required to close by 4 a.m., social clubs often stay open until dawn or later, usually to the distress of nearby residents. Neighborhood residents said Happy Land stayed open until 6 a.m. Often there's a cover charge _ $5 at Happy Land. Often the clubs sell drinks. Many who go to the clubs are looking for a place to socialize that they can afford and where they feel welcome. But they also attract a criminal element. A state task force reported several years ago that alcohol consumption is often of secondary importance. ``The primary function of these operations has developed into prostitution, gambling, drugs and trafficking in stolen property,'' it said. Just Sunday morning, a police task force in Brooklyn raided several social clubs and arrested five people for weapons possession, said Sgt. Tina Mohrmann, a police spokeswoman. Some clubs are closed under the city's ``padlock law,'' which allows police to shutter a location for a year if two crimes are committed on the site within a 12-month period. But the owners _ if they can be found _ are rarely convicted. Defendants arrested in police raids often end up pleading guilty to a lesser charge, which then doesn't qualify as a criminal conviction under the padlock law. Even when the clubs are shuttered, the owners often open up again around the corner or down the street, attracting the same crowd. Then-Mayor Edward Koch put together an interagency task force after the 1988 fire sparked a public outcry about the dangers of social clubs. ``The ironic thing is that all the legislation is on the books,'' said Clint Roswell, a spokesman for Ferrer. ``It's just (an) enforcement problem.''

DOC.HEAD: Alleged Leader Of Drug Ring Pleads Guilty
DOC.TEXT: A man accused of heading a Sicilian drug ring that smuggled heroin and cocaine into New York pleaded guilty to all charges against him, leaving two defendants in a federal trial. Francesco Bellitti, 39, of New York City, admitted to U.S. District Judge Jane R. Roth on Friday that he was a leader of the drug ring. The Northeast drug ring's heroin and cocaine allegedly was sold in Delaware through a pizzeria near Claymont in the northeastern section of the state. Vincent J. Scotto, who owned the pizza shop, is a former member of the gang turned government witness. Belitti faces a maximum sentence of life plus 45 years in prison and fines of $16.5 million in the case, but could get more time behind bars because of a prior drug conviction. He is to be sentenced May 24. Belitti pleaded guilty to three charges of distribution of heroin and one each of conspiracy to distribute cocaine and heroin, interstate travel to commit a crime and racketeering. His attorney, Pat V. Stiso of New York, declined to comment on his client's sudden change of heart. Bellitti also faces deportation after serving his sentence. He told authorities he illegally entered the United States in 1982 from Mexico. According to court papers, Bellitti was convicted in 1973 in Canada of conspiring to import heroin. Federal prosecutor Robert Courtney III told the judge the evidence in the government's case would establish Bellitti as one of two men who organized a 20-member ring that distributed drugs through the Northeast and supervised its operations. The other defendants in the trial, Alexis Telesford and Salvatore Ingrati, both of New York, are accused of helping to set up drug deals and sharing in profits. Testimony was scheduled to resume Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Nicaraguan Cardinal Deplores Rebel Ambush, Urges Contras To Disband
DOC.TEXT: A Roman Catholic Church leader Sunday denounced a rebel ambush in northern Nicaragua that killed 18 people and wounded eight, and he urged the Contras to live up to their agreement to disband immediately. ``This is deplorable. We must hurry so that the agreement signed in Tocontin become a reality,'' Cardinal Miguel Obando y Bravo said in a homily. Obando y Bravo witnessed the accord between representatives of the U.S.-backed rebels and President-elect Violeta Barrios de Chamorro Friday at Tocontin Airport in Tegucigalpa, the capital of neighboring Honduras. ``May the tanks be converted into tractors and that young people devote themselves to producing, so that life becomes better in Nicaragua,'' the cardinal said. While the agreement was being worked out in Honduras, about 100 Contras attacked an army convoy with rockets, mortars and automatic weapons in northern Nicaragua near La Pavona, a town of about 3,000 135 miles north of Managua. The Defense Ministry said 12 army soldiers, five Contras and one civilian were killed in the fighting. Another eight soldiers were wounded, it said. ``Maybe news of the agreement had not reached these people (the rebels) in the mountains,'' Obando y Bravo said. Obando y Bravo urged Mrs. Chamorro, who takes office on April 25, and the Contras to name their delegates to a commission called for in the accord to oversee the demobilization. In La Pavona, Army Lt. Benedicto Martinez said the 600 government soldiers in the area were searching for the Contras and there was scattered fighting around nearby villages. He refused to give details. The attack raised doubts about the viability of the accord, which was not signed by the Contra's chief military commander, Israel Galeano. Only Contra negotiator Oscar Sovalbarro and Mrs. Chamorro's negotiator, Antonio Lacayo, signed the pact. The Sandinistas refused to take part in the negotiations, but President Daniel Ortega said later he backed the agreement. He also expressed concern that Galeano did not take part in the talks or sign the document. Despite the doubts, the accord was seen as a potential breakthrough. The Contras had said they would not disarm until the Sandinista army did. The Sandinistas, in turn, had insisted the Contras lay down their guns first.

DOC.HEAD: 38 Illegal Aliens Found Hiding in Rental Truck
DOC.TEXT: Thirty-eight illegal aliens found cramped and hungry inside a rental truck that broke down in northeast Ohio might have been brought from Mexico to work at farm nurseries, immigration officials said Sunday. U.S. Immigration and Naturalization Service agents were trying to determine who brought the men to Ohio, said Robert Brown, head of the agency's Cleveland office. The aliens were flown back to Mexico on Saturday after being discovered early the same day. Authorities suspect the men were hoping to land work with nurseries, Brown said. Seven of the 38 already had jobs lined up, he said, declining to say where. He said the aliens were ``basically good people who are just trying to do whatever thay can to make a living for their families.'' The men had been carrying counterfeit Social Security and green cards, which are issued as documentation of an alien's permanent, legal U.S. residency. Nearly all lived in an area north of Mexico City, Brown said. Each paid $300 to $600 to make the trip, and more than half had paid up to $60 for counterfeit documents, he said. Chardon police said a resident complained early Saturday about a rental truck seen in the northeastern Ohio village and men acting suspiciously. When police located the 12-foot-long truck, they found the aliens huddled in the back. Village Interim Police Chief Steve Gazdik said the truck had broken down and the driver might have fled before police arrived. ``It's possible that the driver was an alien as well,'' Gazdik said. ``But we aren't sure.'' Gazdik said the group, including two teen-agers, endured cramped and unsanitary conditions, and may not have eaten for two to five days. He said they may have been headed to orchards and nurseries in Ashtabula County. The truck was rented March 15, and the men boarded in Tijuana, Mexico, and entered the United States through Southern California, Brown said.

DOC.HEAD: Dying Cancer Victims Selling Pain Pills To Pay For Funeral Costs
DOC.TEXT: Dying cancer patients have been raising money by selling their pain pills to a drug ring, authorities say. ``It's a pitiful sight,'' said Sgt. Raymond Lee, a narcotics investigator with the West Columbia Police Department. ``They're so poor they're willing to take an aspirin and put up with the pain.'' Five people were arrested in the case, police said Sunday. Drug dealers befriended other patients who refused to sell their pills, called Dilaudid, and then stole the medicine from them, Lee said last week. Other times, relatives of patients stole the pills and sold them for about $25 each to the drug dealers, he said. The patients usually are given Dilaudid to ease the suffering during their final days. The dealers sold the tiny yellow pills to heroin addicts for about $40 each, Lee said. The addicts pound the pills into a powder, which they inject into their veins. Police identified those arrested as Patty Carlini, 34, of West Columbia, Wanda Oree, 28, of West Columbia, and Karen C. Jackson, 34, Columbia. They were charged with distribution of a controlled substance, distribution within proximity of a school and conspiracy to distribute a controlled substance, police said. The two others arrested were Nin B. Nissen, 39, of Columbia, and Ronald Burgess, 44, of Columbia, police said. The charges against them were not immediately known. Most of the cancer patients being treated at the Veterans Administration Hospital and got their pills free, said West Columbia Police Chief H.C. Salters. ``One cancer patient's profits would range up to $2,500 a month by selling the drug he had gotten from the V.A. Hospital,'' Salters said. The sick patients who sold the drugs weren't arrested, Lee said. But officials were investigating some patients who may have been deceiving doctors by saying they were sick to get drugs to sell. ``I don't want to come down hard on the V.A.,'' Lee said. ``But they've been handing these things out in bundles.'' The FBI said through a spokesman Sunday that the agency wasn't investigating the federally-run hospital. Robert Athey, director of the hospital, said he was unaware of the allegations concerning cancer patients.

DOC.HEAD: GOP Gubernatorial Nominee's Remark Decried
DOC.NOTE: Eds: DELETES extraneous word, ``enjoy,'' in lead.
DOC.TEXT: Republican gubernatorial nominee Clayton Williams said Sunday his off-the-cuff remark suggesting victims of rape should ``relax and enjoy it'' was insensitive, after initially downplaying it as just a joke. Women's groups and the millionaire rancher's political foes reacted with outrage. State Treasurer Ann Richards, who is in the April 10 runoff for the Democratic nomination, said Sunday that Williams seemed not to realize that rape is a crime of violence. While preparing for a cattle round-up at his West Texas ranch Saturday, Williams compared the cold, foggy weather spoiling the event to a rape. ``If it's inevitable, just relax and enjoy it,'' Williams said to ranch hands, campaign workers and reporters sitting around a campfire. On Sunday, his campaign issued a statement in which he said: ``I feel just terrible about this. I had no intention in my heart to hurt anyone especially those women who have traumatized by rape. ``Looking back, I realize it was insensitive and had no place at the campfire or in any setting,'' the statement said. Williams, who is making his first run for public office, initially downplayed the remark. On Saturday he said it was a joke and he apologized ``if anyone's offended.'' Pressed further for an explanation for the remark, Williams said: ``That's not a Republican women's club that we were having this morning. It's a working cow camp, a tough world where you can get kicked in the testicles if you're not careful.'' Asked if some people might be offended, Williams said: ``I'm not going to give you a serious answer. It wasn't a serious deal. It wasn't a serious statement.'' Marilyn Rickman, head of the Texas Women's Political Caucus, which has endorsed Ms. Richards for governor, said Saturday that Williams' remark was inexcusable. ``Rape is never a joke with (women) under any circumstance,'' she said. ``I don't think I know any woman who would say, `Hey, sit back and enjoy it.''' ``He needs a brain transplant,'' reacted Joyce Gersh, chairman of the Houston-area National Organization for Women, which also has endorsed Ms. Richards. ``Anyone who is not sexist would not have come up with that remark,'' she said. Williams' wife, Modesta, and several Republicans defended him. ``If the word rape was in a joke, if sex was in a joke, it was just a joke,'' she said. ``He's about as much of a gentleman, a caring person, as there is.'' ``It's an old joke which we've heard a million times,'' said State Republican Executive Committee member Virginia Steenson. ``He certainly couldn't have meant that seriously.'' Williams won the March 13 GOP primary over three major challengers, spending more than $6 million of his oil, ranching and business fortune on the campaign. He has said he owns no shoes, only cowboy boots, and his campaign TV commercials often featured him wearing a cowboy hat. Williams will face either Ms. Richards or Attorney General Jim Mattox in the November general election. The two Democrats meet in a runoff April 10, because unlike Williams, neither one gained a simple majority in their party's primary. Ms. Richards said the remark ``questions his ability to understand the kinds of problems faced by the people of Texas. Rape is a crime of violence.'' ``Just because you're in the barnyard doesn't mean you have to act like Clayton Williams does,'' Mattox said. ``I just think that women voters are going to remember his attitude about this.''

DOC.HEAD: Train Hits Bumper at Station, More Than Two Dozen Reported Injured
DOC.TEXT: At least one person remained hospitalized Sunday after an Amtrak train crashed into a bumper at the end of a track at Union Station, sending about 60 people to hospitals, officials said. In another accident involving an Amtrak train, a 20-year-old man was hit and killed in Philadelphia on Saturday night by a train as he fled railroad police, authorities said. The ``City of New Orleans'' train out of New Orleans was arriving in Chicago with 254 passengers when the accident happened around 11:30 a.m. Saturday. The train hit the bumper block, derailing eight of 10 cars and tossing passengers and luggage around, Amtrak spokesman John Jacobsen said in a telephone interview from Washington, D.C. ``It was like someone rear-ended you,'' passenger Jim Hewitt said Saturday. About 60 people were treated at hospitals and released, officials said. Terry Frantz, 44, of New Orleans was in fair condition Sunday at Northwestern Memorial Hospital. He was under observation after complaining of shortness of breath and strain to his neck and back, said hospital spokesman James Henri. The cause of the accident wasn't immediately determined. Butler said the train was traveling at 3-4 mph when it failed to stop the normal car length from the station, instead crashing into the concrete-and-steel bumper post. In the Philadelphia accident, Samuel Cohn was hit by the ``Connecticut Yankee,'' which was traveling at an estimated 105 mph, shortly after 8 p.m. Saturday, police said. Cohn and a group of friends were on the Amtrak right-of-way and may have been drinking when Amtrak police arrived at 8 p.m., police said. As Cohn fled, he tried to cross tracks in front of the Washington-to-Springfield, Mass. train, authorities said. The engineer, whose name was withheld, didn't see the man in time, Jacobsen said. The train was delayed half an hour.

DOC.HEAD: Fire Kills 87 at Unlicensed Social Club; Man Charged
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 26th graf to CORRECT spelling to Ungar sted Unger.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos NY7,8,11,16,19,27; LaserColor NY6,15; LaserGraphic NY25
DOC.TEXT: Fire raced through an illegal social club early Sunday and turned a packed dance floor into a deathtrap of smoke and flame that killed 87. A man who allegedly had earlier fought with a club worker was charged with arson and murder. The fire, the nation's worst in 13 years, tore through the Happy Land club, which authorities said lacked proper exits and other safeguards. The 3:40 a.m. fire killed 61 men and 26 women, most of them Honduran and Dominican immigrants. Most were found on the second floor. ``People literally were stacked on top of each other,'' said Anthony De Vita, the Fire Department's command chief. ``It was a firetrap,'' he said of the two-story building in an impoverished neighborhood near the Bronx Zoo. Some of the victims broke a hole through a wall to an adjoining hall in a desperate attempt to save their lives, said Red Cross worker Margaret Glugover. Julio Gonzalez, 36, was charged with arson and murder in the case, said Lt. Raymond O'Donnell, a police spokesman. The district attorney's office later would determine how many counts Gonzalez would be charged. ``We believe the motive in this case was the result of a dispute he had with a female employee of the club,'' Police Commissioner Lee Brown said at a City Hall news conference Sunday evening. Gonzalez emigrated in 1980 from Cuba during the Mariel boatlift that brought 125,000 Cubans to the United States. Police said Gonzalez went into the club about 3 a.m. and began arguing with his former girlfriend, who sold tickets near the entrance. ``He's trying to talk her into making up, she's saying `Leave me alone,''' O'Donnell said. A club bouncer evicted the man half an hour later, and police alleged he returned and started the fire near the entrance. The woman employee left before the fire, Brown said. At least two women and one man, believed to be the club's disc jockey, escaped. The man was seriously burned; the condition of the women was unknown. Most of the dead were believed to have suffocated from the thick smoke, which billowed hundreds of feet, but some were trampled, said Lynn Schulman, an Emergency Medical Service spokeswoman. ``This is the worst thing I have seen in my career,'' said Emergency Medical Services specialist Christopher McCarthy. ``It hurt my stomach. It was sickening.'' ``Most of the bodies were in dance clothes,'' McCarthy said. ``They were out to have fun. ... I saw wall-to-wall bodies _ an indication of mass confusion and panic.'' The fire was the deadliest in the continental United States since a May 28, 1977, blaze at the Beverly Hills Supper Club in Southgate, Ky., that killed 164 people. A Dec. 31, 1986, fire at a hotel in San Juan, Puerto Rico, a U.S. commonwealth, killed 96 people. The tragedy occurred in East Tremont, a section of the Bronx borough. Deputy Mayor Bill Lynch described it as an ``economically disadvantaged, working-class, Latino neighborhood.'' The building housed a group that organized children's baseball as well as adult social events, said Lillian Rivera, a neighbor. A makeshift morgue was set up at a hall next door. Authorities took Polaroid pictures of the bodies and showed them to 200 friends and relatives at a school across the street where the cries and wails of relatives could be heard outside. Then, the bodies were moved to a hospital morgue. After viewing the bodies, Mayor David Dinkins called the scene ``graphic and sad.'' Dinkins said a vacate order was issued in November 1988 because the club lacked a proper sprinkler system, exits, emergency lighting and signs. City records show the club was again ordered closed on Nov. 1, 1989, by the Buildings Department, Dinkins said. ``I don't know what subsequent visits were made there,'' the mayor said. The club had no liquor or cabaret license. Two neighborhood residents said three gunshots were heard just before the fire. Robert Ungar, deputy fire commissioner, said he could not confirm another report that cans of accelerant were found. So-called ``social clubs'' proliferate in New York City's poor neighborhoods, and despite their name many of them admit virtually anyone who wants to enter, functioning essentially as unlicensed taverns or dance clubs. New York police officials have estimated that alcohol is sold without a license at more than 200 locations. Authorities said the victims tried to escape the windowless club down a stairway just wide enough for one person. A second stairway apparently wasn't used, perhaps because it couldn't be reached from the club. Sixty-nine of the victims died upstairs, where the dance floor was located. ``People were screaming; they were all burned,'' said Rosemary Green, who found the club on fire when she arrived to meet her sister-in-law and cousin. ``Once you got in the entrance there was no way to get out.'' Denise Garcia, 20, a filing clerk who lives in the neighborhood, said she and her friends avoided the club because they considered it ``too sleazy.'' The building was rickety and the dance floor sometimes trembled, she said. Ms. Garcia said the club's patrons included many illegal immigrants. The tragedy occurred on the 79th anniversary of the Triangle Shirtwaist Co. fire in Manhattan, which killed 145 people, most of them immigrant garment workers, and led to reforms governing workplace safety. EMS Lt. Roy David said he got to the scene just as the male survivor was staggering out. ``He walked toward me. He couldn't talk. He couldn't say anything. All we could do was treat him,'' David said. Five firefighters, including a battalion chief who broke his leg, were taken to Jacobi after inhaling smoke. Six other firefighters were treated at the scene for smoke inhalation.

DOC.HEAD: Honduran Woman's American Dream Shattered by Club Fire
With AM-Social Club Fire
DOC.TEXT: Two and one-half years ago, Alva Romero left Honduras full of hope that life would be better in the United States. Her dreams came crashing down Sunday when six members of her family were killed in a fire at an illegal social club that claimed a total of 87 lives. ``We came here to better ourselves but this is what we get,'' a grief-stricken Romero said moments after confirming that her two brothers, a sister, her daughter, a cousin and a niece had perished in the early morning fire at the Happy Land club. It wasn't political upheaval or severe dissatisfaction with Honduras that brought her here, she said. It was, quite simply, opportunity. ``This is America. We all would have a chance to do better here,'' she said as she dabbed her eyes. ``Now, I don't know. ...'' Here, the 34-year-old woman worked in people's homes, helping the elderly and sick to feed and clothe themselves. But on Sunday, it was friends and relatives who helped Romero at a nearby school, where the bereaved were taken to learn the awful truth. The brothers were 33 and 21 years old; the sister, daughter and cousin all were 18; the niece, 17. Her husband had remained in Honduras. ``They had been to the club before and they liked it,'' Romero said. ``It had been three weeks since they had been there.'' ``And, last night,'' she said, her voice choking with emotion, ``Last night, they all decided to go back to the club. I don't know why.'' Nelson Moll, a Red Cross volunteer, said Romero was one of the first to show up at the school at about 10 a.m. where photographs of the dead were displayed. When she saw the pictures of her family, Romero slumped forward, devastated by the news. ``She looked at the pictures and she just broke down pretty bad,'' he said. Six hours later, after viewing the photographs and the bodies at the morgue, a still-shocked Romero passively, almost distantly, answered reporters' questions. Will she stay in the United States? ``I don't know. Everything is changed. I don't know.''

DOC.HEAD: Allegations of Secret Police Links Threaten Coalition Talks
DOC.TEXT: Efforts to form the country's first democratic government faltered Sunday because of mounting charges of past ties between political leaders and the hated secret police. Social Democratic Party leader Ibrahim Boehme, the latest politician to come under suspicion of having collaborated with the secret police, called for all coalition talks to be suspended until the allegations are investigated. In its latest issue, the West German newsmagazine Der Spiegel said two former agents of the police, known as Stasi, had denounced Boehme as a regular secret collaborator. Boehme forcefully denied the charge in a letter to members of the left-leaning party. Lothar de Maiziere, leader of the conservative Christian Democratic Union that won the nation's first free parliamentary elections on March 18, is also trying to counter reports he, too, was a Stasi informer. The West German newspaper Cologne Express has said de Maiziere had the code name ``Scerny'' in the files of the secret police, who for years enforced the repressive tactics of the hard-line Communist regime. De Maiziere, the front-runner to head the new government, has denied informing for the police. An official in charge of dismantling the Stasi has said many newly elected lawmakers may have been informers. East Germany's chief prosecutor has ruled out an inquiry before the new parliament is actually seated. On Sunday, however, Boehme said talks on a government coalition between the Social Democrats and the Christian Democrats should not be held until after an investigation. He said the delay would serve the ``national interest.'' The Social Democrats came in second in the elections. The West German government is urging the two parties to form a coalition that would ensure the parliamentary majority in East Germany needed to speed unification. Bonn has said it expects the new 400-member East German parliament to be seated early next month and to name a premier and Cabinet soon afterward. Preparations for a currency union between the German states are proceeding quickly and the merger will take effect July 1, the West German Welt am Sonntag newspaper reported Sunday. The monetary union, a major step toward full Germany unity, would replace East Germany's noncovertible currency with West Germany's powerful mark. The newspaper also published a timetable under which East Germany would assume West Germany's pension system and unemployment benefits by Sept. 1. The paper said the timetable was worked out during talks in Bonn earlier this month involving West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl and Finance Minister Theo Waigel, and leaders of East Germany's Alliance for Germany. The alliance is a three-party group that ran as a coalition in the elections. It includes the Christian Democrats. Waigel told Welt am Sonntag that East German savers will be able to change their marks for West German marks at a 1-1 rate ``up to a certain limit.'' He gave no details. The finance minister also said West Germany will assume East Germany's foreign debt, but the size of the debt was unclear, according to the newspaper.

DOC.HEAD: Rocket Launched On Third Attempt
DOC.TEXT: The Air Force on Sunday night launched a Delta 2 rocket carrying a $65 million navigation satellite after two earlier postponements, a spokeswoman said. The rocket had been scheduled for liftoff Tuesday night, and that was postponed to Wednesday night. Strong upper-atmosphere winds forced a second delay. The launch at 9:45 p.m. EST was without incident. ``Everything looks real good,'' Sgt. Ivey Paige said. The satellite separated from the rocket's third stage as planned and was in a preliminary, relatively low orbit. It was expected to reach its final orbit in a few days, said Ken Warren, a NASA spokesman. The payload is the seventh in a series of advanced Navstar satellites launched in the past year from Cape Canaveral. The navigation system is designed to provide the United States and allied land, sea and air forces with worldwide three-dimensional position and velocity information. By 1992, the Air Force plans to have 21 of the spacecraft orbiting the Earth to form a global network.

DOC.HEAD: Survivors: Fishing Boat Alarm Failed Before Capsizing in Bering Sea
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 2nd graf to UPDATE with crewmen saying they'd been given little instruction on using survival suits; INSERTS 7 grafs after 10th graf, ```The information ...,' to UPDATE with comments; picks up 11th graf, `The Aleutian ...' DELETES now-redundant grafs 18-19, `Stevenson said ...'
DOC.TEXT: Survivors of a vessel that listed and quickly sank in the icy Bering Sea say an alarm failed to sound and may have cost some of the nine missing crewmen their lives, an investigator said Sunday. ``At least two of the crew I interviewed said they felt that the delay didn't allow people to search for survival gear or to get to the deck'' before the fish-processing ship Aleutian Enterprise rolled and sank within minutes of listing to port Thursday, said Alaska State Trooper Robert Stevenson. Two crew members said they'd been given little or no instruction in using flotation suits designed to protect against the arctic waters. Stevenson, stationed at Dutch Harbor about 800 miles southwest of Anchorage, said several survivors told him the alarm system had not worked for months. Stevenson interviewed 21 of the 22 survivors. The nine people from the Seattle-based trawler are missing and presumed drowned. Dan Roberts, executive vice president of Arctic Alaska Fisheries Corp., the company that operates the vessel, said Saturday he didn't know why the alarm might have failed to sound or have been inoperable. Company officials did not return telephone messages left Sunday with a secretary. ``I just went on instinct. The people all around me were screaming, `Help me! Help me!,'' crewman Derrik Santy told the Anchorage Daily News Saturday as he waited in line at Anchorage International Airport for a ticket home to Seattle. Santy said he was below deck when the ship began to roll in calm seas about 60 miles south of Saint Paul Island on Thursday afternoon. Scrambling to the deck, Santy jumped into the water and ``grabbed anything that floated.'' He said he was in the water with the other 21 survivors for about 10 minutes when they were picked up a sister ship, the Pacific Enterprise. Stevenson said ships are supposed to be equipped with general alarms, some of which sound automatically when the vessel lists too far. The alarm also can be sounded manually from the wheelhouse, he said. ``The information we have is it just didn't work and hasn't worked for some time,'' Stevenson said. Santy, 18, of Seattle said Sunday that he received little instruction on using flotation suits. ``The only thing they told me about survival suits was they're in these lockers and that's all,'' he said in an interview with Seattle television station KING. In reply to a question, he said he didn't know how to put the suits on. ``Shoot, I never saw one before.'' Crew member Matt Price, 19, of Aberdeen, Wash., said he searched a locker for a survival suit, but didn't have time to get one. ``That was my first time being on a boat and they should have explained the procedure if it was going to sink,'' Price said. ``They never did that.'' Stevenson said none of the crew members managed to don survival suits. He said water temperatures in the Bering Sea are in the low 30s and people die of shock in such cold water ``fairly quickly.'' The Aleutian Enterprise, a 162-foot, 195-ton cod fishing and processing factory trawler, sank about 250 miles northwest of Dutch Harbor. The ship, owned by a group of California investors, was operated by Arctic Alaska. The company operates 22 other vessels, the largest trawler fleet in the Bering Sea. Stevenson said survivors told him some crewmen were pulling in a netload of fish when the vessel started listing to port. The skipper, Mark Siemons, slackened the line and, gave full power to the starboard engine and took other actions in an attempt to right the 195-ton vessel, Stevenson said. ``It didn't work. It continued to list and then capsized. It sank within five minutes of capsizing,'' he said. He said survivors told him a handful of crewmen were off duty and sleeping below deck when the trawler began to list, and some were roused by other crew members and the commotion. The skipper, meanwhile, managed to radio a sister ship for help. Some survivors scrambled into two lifeboats and others clung to floatation devices or debris until another trawler arrived 15 or 20 minutes later, Stevenson said. Coast Guard spokesman Greg Robinson said investigators interviewed 10 crew members as they arrived at Anchorage International Airport from Dutch Harbor. National Transportation Safety Board investigators and lawyers representing the vessel's owners also participated in the closed interviews, he said. The ship had set out from Dutch Harbor on March 2 and was to have returned Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Brazil's President Orders Airstrips Dynamited to Keep Off Miners
DOC.TEXT: President Fernando Collor de Mello ordered the destruction of about 100 clandestine Amazon jungle airstrips to keep thousands of gold miners from returning to land reserved for Indians. ``Dynamite them, and be fast about it,'' the new president told federal police chief Romeu Tuma on Saturday while visiting Roraima state in the northwest Amazon. During the trip, his first since taking office March 15, Collor also visited an Indian village and flew over mining camps ordered shut by former President Jose Sarney. The order to destroy the airstrips was given to keep an estimated 40,000 miners from returning to lands owned by the Yanomami Indians, the world's largest remaining primitive tribe. Last week, the government reported the end of an 80-day operation to force miners off Indian lands and onto three mining reserves. However, Roman Catholic Church officials say some miners still remain on Yanomami territory. Collor promised ``a solution without conflicts'' when about 500 people greeted him at the airport in Boa Vista, the Roraima state capital, 3,682 miles northwest of Rio de Janeiro. ``We must respect, without a doubt, our brother Indians, but we must also respect those who take from the land what is necessary to kill their hunger,'' the president said. The invasion of Yanomami lands by the miners began three years ago, when it was discovered the Indians lived on reserves rich in minerals, especially gold and diamonds. The miners have scared away fish and game, polluted rivers and streams and also brought diseases previously unknown to the Yanomami. Since 1987, the tribe's numbers have fallen from about 9,000 to 7,500 because of malnutrition, venereal diseases and malaria. Others have died in armed conflicts with miners. The government has steadily carved up Indian lands, reducing the Yanomami to territories totaling 5 million acres on 19 scattered reservations. The tribe once claimed 23 million acres of the Amazon forest along Brazil's northern border with Venezuela, Guyana and Colombia.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Attends Fund-Raising Gala
DOC.NOTE: EDS: puppeteer in 2nd graf uses no first name
DOC.TEXT: President Bush sat through nearly three hours of entertainment in historic Ford's Theatre Sunday night and afterwards quipped that Abraham Lincoln ``would have really enjoyed this program _ parts of it.'' The show was an annual fund-raising gala for Ford's Theatre, and the talent ranged from scat singer Diane Schuur to dancing puppeteer Christopher to the Gatlin Brothers to Tony Bennett to comic Jim Morris, who did a wicked imitation of both Bush and his predecessor, Ronald Reagan. The show, ``A Festival at Ford's,'' will be televised on Ted Turner's Broadcasting System on the night of July 4. This April 14 is the 125th anniversary of the night when Lincoln, the 16th president, was assassinated by John Wilkes Booth in the presidential box at Ford's Theatre. Bush, an avid theater-goer himself, recalled that Lincoln loved to go to the theater. The night that Booth struck was Lincoln's tenth visit to Ford's. ``He loved entertainment. ... and I believe he would have really enjoyed this program _ parts of it,'' said Bush, to laughter and applause from the audience of more than 500. The theater, closed after the assassination, remained dark for 103 years until it was restored by Congress and the National Park Service in 1968 as both a museum and a living theater. Rep. Sidney Yates, D-Ill., received the Lincoln Medal from the theater's trustees for his advocacy of the arts. Frankie Hewitt, the theater's executive director, said that in recent years, amid congressional efforts to censor National Endowment for the Arts grants, Yates had ``quite literally protected the integrity of the arts for all Americans.'' Yates, who last week survived a tough primary fight, drew applause in turn when he applauded Bush ``for the great statement you made ... in support of the arts.'' Bush last Friday said he opposes attempts to write into law anti-pornography restrictions on NEA grants. ``I am deeply offended by some of the filth that I see and to which federal money has gone and some of the sacrilegious, blasphemous depictions that are portrayed by some to be art,'' Bush said. But he said he prefers to let his new NEA director, John Frohnmayer, use his discretion rather ``than risk censorship of getting the federal government into telling every artist what he or she can paint, or how he or she might express themselves.''

DOC.HEAD: Officials Hope Spring, New Hotels Offset Sluggish Winter
DOC.TEXT: Unpredictable weather, redevelopment and shaky attempts to reach new markets added up to a bad winter for the Lake Tahoe resort in California and Nevada, tourism officials said. But officials are optimistic the economy has bottomed out and that new hotel development at pristine Sierra Lake and possible events such as the Miss USA Pageant will help Tahoe rebound. The number of rooms booked on the California side of the popular resort fell 8.22 percent in July-December 1989 compared with the same period in 1988. For January, the figure was 17.6 percent below January 1988. Room tax collections on the California side, which relies on ski resorts to lure winter tourists, dropped 2.3 percent to $2.9 million in the last half of 1989 compared with the same period a year earlier. The casino-lined Nevada side of the lake showed a 1 percent increase in room taxes in the same period. Improvement in January pushed the rise to 2 percent for the seven-month period. ``Things were pretty bad this winter,'' Kathleen Farrell, executive director of the Tahoe-Douglas Chamber of Commerce, said Friday. ``The lack of snow hurt us and a controversy over how to market the area exists about whether to go after skiers in the winter or not and where to advertise.'' Ski resorts peppered the Dallas-Fort Worth market with ads this winter to attract visitors who usually go to Colorado slopes, but a lack of significant snow kept Texans away. When storms did hit they typically came on Fridays, causing many drive-up tourist from northern California to stay home. ``The last time I saw such bad timing of storms was six years ago,'' Ms. Farrell said. ``We'd look out the window and say, `It's storming. It must be Friday.' That's how it was this winter.'' In May, the Tahoe tourism authority plans to launch a $320,000 advertising campaign to run through September in Los Angeles to attract summer visitors to the lake and, with hope, make up for the poor winter. Negotiations are continuing to bring the 1991 Miss USA Pageant to Reno-Tahoe in February or March. ``I think that in the past two months we've already started to turn the situation around and so things aren't as alarming as they appear to be,'' said Barbara Klein, executive director of the Lake Tahoe Visitors Authority at South Lake Tahoe, Calif. Ms. Klein said ground will be broken in April and May for two new hotel projects at South Lake Tahoe, bordering the Stateline, Nev., casino row that sits above the lake about 35 miles southwest of Reno. About 900 old motel rooms in the city were torn down to allow construction of a 400-room Embassy Suites hotel and a 320-room still-unnamed hotel. Tahoe tourism authorities also have hired people to greet passengers flying into the Reno Cannon International Airport and are putting together mini-vacation packages to lure visitors to stay longer than a weekend. An estimated 2.5 million to 3 million people visit Lake Tahoe each year with many staying overnight in one of the 11,000 hotel and motel rooms around the 72-mile shoreline, Ms. Klein said.

DOC.HEAD: Treasury Chief Expects Inflation, Interest Rates To Decline
DOC.TEXT: Britain's top treasury official said Sunday he expects the nation's 7.7 percent inflation rate and 15 percent interest rates to be ``materially lower'' by 1991. ``In due course, it would be very nice to get inflation down to nil but inflation doesn't suddenly come down to nil and stay there forever,'' Chancellor of the Exchequer John Major said. Major said in a British Broadcasting Corp. television interview that inflation and interest rates ``will be materially lower at the beginning of next year, at the middle of next year, at the end of next year and in 1992.'' Britain's inflation rate has sat at 7.7 percent, despite the government's high interest-rate policy, and economists predict it could climb as high as 9 percent. Major, the treasury's top official, said in his budgetary statement earlier this month that inflation is worse in Britain than in other countries because of heavy borrowing and strong consumer spending.

DOC.HEAD: Tentative Agreement Reached in Hawaii Hotel Workers Strike
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 16 grafs to UPDATE with terms of agreement, comment; Edits to conform; PICKS UP 15th graf pvs, `The strike...; A version containing some of material moved on general news wires for Sunday AMs
DOC.TEXT: Workers at 11 Hawaii hotels achieved a goal of parity with mainland workers under a tentative agreement ending a month-long strike that left some hotel guests making their own beds, labor leaders said. The deal between Local 5 of the Hotel Employees and Restaurant Employees and the Council of Hawaii Hotels would give workers an average pay increase of 10 percent a year. The strike affected about one-fourth of the 37,000 hotel rooms in Waikiki, the state's tourist capital, and about one-seventh of the state's total number of hotel rooms. ``As is the case with all contracts, we didn't get everything we want, but we did (satisfy) our needs,'' union leader Tony Rutledge said after the agreement was announced Saturday. Nearly 80 percent of workers will be earning nearly as much money as hotel workers in San Francisco by the time the contract expires in 1994, Rutledge said, meeting one of the union's main goals. The walkout by 7,500 maids, bellhops, clerks, restaurant and bar workers and others left some hotel guests doing without room service and making their own beds as managers struggled to fill the gaps. Some of the affected hotels offered discounts of up to 20 percent. The tentative accord, reached after an all-night bargaining session, was announced by union and management representatives, Gov. John Waihee and federal mediator Frank Schoeppel. ``This will give stability to the industry for the next five years,'' said William Crawford, executive director of the management council and chief negotiator for the hotels. The union achieved its main goal of bringing pay in line with that of mainland hotel workers, union spokesman Roderick Rodriguez said. Union members were to meet Sunday to discuss the settlement and procedures for ratification. But members were told they didn't need to wait for formal ratification and could return to work as soon as their hotels called for them to come in. Under the agreement, wages and benefits for non-tipped workers will increase 7 percent this year and 6 percent each of the next four years. Tipped workers will get raises totaling 85 cents an hour over the life of the contract. Workers also will get an increase of 99 cents an hour in health and other benefits to bring the total to $2.29 an hour. The union failed to win a 5 percent room surcharge or a 15 percent food and beverage surcharge that would have been divided among workers, two issues it had labeled critical for a settlement. Rutledge said the tentative agreement would add about 40 cents per hour across the board to the one approved at another Hawaiian hotel. The union had been seeking increases of about 10 percent a year for three years. Salaries under the old contract range from an average of $3.85 an hour for bellhops to an average of $11.04 an hour for cooks. Waihee intervened out of concern for the state's $6-billion-a-year tourist industry. The strike, which began Feb. 24, affected eight hotels on Oahu and three on the neighbor islands. The affected hotels on Oahu were the Hilton Hawaiian Village, 2,523 rooms; Sheraton Waikiki, 1,900 rooms; Hyatt Regency Waikiki, 1,250 rooms; Princess Kalulani, 1,150 rooms; Ilikai Hotel, 800 rooms; Sheraton Moana Surfrider, 793 rooms; Royal Hawaiian, 525 rooms; and Kahala Hilton, 369 rooms. Neighbor island hotels affected are the Sharaton Maui, 495 rooms; Sheraton Kauai, 456 rooms; and Kona Hilton, 445 rooms. In addition, two other hotels, the Turtle Bay Hilton and Royal Waikoloan, agreed to abide by terms of the settlement.

DOC.HEAD: St. Joseph Families Await the Minimum Wage Hike
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf pvs, `But a...' and 6th graf pvs, `Her employer..., to CORRECT verb agreement; PICKS UP 7th graf pvs, `I know...; Also moved on general news wires
DOC.TEXT: A sign outside this red bricked town along the Missouri River proudly proclaims it's the place where the Pony Express began and Jesse James ended. But empty warehouses, vacant storefronts and quiet rail yards are grim reminders that the glory days for St. Joseph, like many towns in the manufacturing Midwest, are long past. For residents with few skills, the only jobs around are those paying minimum wage or just above. Hundreds of high paying jobs vanished when meat packing plants closed and the farm crisis set in. Those scraping by at the bottom of the wage scale have been looking forward to April 1, when the minimum wage goes up 45 cents an hour, from $3.35 to $3.80. It's the first such hike for the working poor since 1981. ``It doesn't sound like much, really, but it would help us out,'' said Diane Fanning, who supports an 8-year-old daughter on a $4.10-an-hour job making beds and doing other chores at a nursing home. Her employer, like businesses across the country that pay above $3.80 an hour, is faced with the dilemma of whether to provide raises to rival the hike in the minimum wage. ``I know how to stretch a penny; I have to. But there's not much money to do anything right now, not for the extras, anyway. It would let us maybe go do something once in a while,'' Fanning said of a 45-cent raise that would translate into about $18 more a week. She now takes home around $140 a week, she said. Under the measure passed by Congress last year, the 4 million Americans who make the minimum wage will see the hourly rate go to $4.25 on April 1, 1991. It also establishes a ``training wage'' for teen-agers first entering the work force, which will be $3.35 an hour this year and $3.61 an hour in 1991. Had the minimum wage kept pace with inflation since 1981, it would have been $4.59 an hour in 1989 and $5.28 an hour by 1992, supporters said. ``I've been waiting on this for a long time,'' said Tim Turrieta, another nurse's aide at the Carriage Square Health Care Center. ``Our wages have been holding steady, but the economy's been running away. It's only fair that we get something.'' ``It's going to let you buy that pair of shoes you've been looking at but haven't been able to afford,'' Turrieta said. But to others, the increase is so long overdue it won't have much impact. Low-wage workers also fear bigger paychecks might translate into higher grocery and clothing prices. ``After they raise it to where a man can start to make it, I'm afraid the economy and the price of everything else will just take off too,'' said Greg Fairchild, who helps support four children on a $3.60-an-hour cook's job at Burger King. Without his wife's $865-a-month take home pay as a psychiatric aide, his family wouldn't make it, he said. Though St. Joseph's downtown business district has suffered in recent years, its three-mile strip of fast food and retail establishments _ known as the Belt _ has continued to grow. The good paying jobs in St. Joseph, a town of 76,000 located 50 miles north of Kansas City, are at the lone meat packing plant left in town, a wire rope manufacturer, the Mead paper plant and Quaker Oats. ``Being in the heart of the farm belt, we suffered with the agriculture crisis, but things have improved significantly,'' said Alan Kenyon, president of the area's Chamber of Commerce. He noted that a pet food firm is opening a test facility soon and that more than 30 stores have just been added to the expanded shopping mall at the edge of town. Unemployment posted a relatively low 5.5 percent rate last year, the same level as the entire state. One county in southeast Missouri suffered a 15 percent jobless rate. Merchants here paying low wages don't think workers will get much benefit from a few more nickels an hour. ``The dollars just pass from one hand to another. Who's really gained from all of it?'' said Clara Lash, who runs the 120-bed facility where Fanning and Turrieta work. Nina Casey, who owns the Sav-On Unclaimed Merchandise and Furniture store out on the Belt, said the increase won't hurt her profit margin. ``It's no skin off our nose, because we'll just raise the prices to match it,'' Casey said. ``Your bottom line has to stay the same. Any third-grader can tell you that. So how does their (minimum wage workers') purchasing power increase any?'' She contends nearly all of those workers at the tail end of the wage scale are using the job as a second income. ``No one's making a living off the minimum wage. They can't make a living at $4 an hour either,'' Ms. Casey said. Lash said her ability to pay matching 45-cent raises will depend on whether Medicaid increases its reimbursement rates. ``I can't make promises to my staff that they're going to get the ripple effect,'' she said. ``I'd love to give it to them. They're doing a job here that nobody else wants to do.'' Larry Huston, president of the AFL-CIO's northwest Missouri region, said the minimum wage will still be too low. ``Everybody deserves a livable wage. I wouldn't call $3.35 an hour that _ or $3.80, for that matter,'' Huston said. ``I don't know how in the world people get by on that, God bless 'em. They must be better skimpers than me.''
